Posted: August 20, 2013
												You're thrown into an open world. You're given targets that you must kill, and in some instances, objectives to complete. That's it, the rest is up to you. You decide your weapon of choice to pull off the perfect hit; will it be the pistol? Shotgun? Assault Rifle? Submachine Gun? Sniper Rifle? You can spend the money that you earn from hits on different upgrades. Will you opt for a silencer on your pistol, or will you spend it on improved lockpicking skills? There are multiple different playstyles, and the choice is entirely up to you. Will you run in, guns blazing, killing anything that stands between you and your target? Or will you sneak in, using a disguise you stole from a guard that is now unconcious in the dumpster? How will you kill your targets? Will you poison their food? Strangle them? Snipe them? Rig a chandelier to fall on them? You choose how you play the game. You choose your definition of a perfect hit. First time players beware, however, you will find yourself spending lots of time doing trial-and-error to find the best ways to kill your target. If you enjoy games with linear gameplay where there's only one way to win, then you will probably not enjoy this game. However, if you want a sandbox stealth experience, where you get to decide how the game will play out, at $8.99, this game is perfect for you.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												I've owned and played all of the Hitman franchise, both on consoles and on the PC (non-steam), and I've thoroughly enjoyed each one. I think my favorite games in the franchise are Silent Assassin and Contracts, however, each game is a wonderful experience and should be given at least one playthrough if you have the chance.If you like stealth-oriented (or guns-blazing) gameplay, being a dangerous assassin, and open-ended, challenging missions, then you will really, really enjoy this game. The Hitman franchise has consistently been able to provide the experience of being a world-renown and package it into a fun, fresh, and user-friendly game for all types of gamers to enjoy.The aesthetics are fantastic - the detail in the environments and character models are very well-done. The music and sounds in the franchise have always been solid, and the score used in Blood Money adds a sense of grandiosity and elegance to the gameplay. The story has always been interesting, and this installation chronicles the FBI's hunt for Agent 47. The "ending" is quite satisfying, and offers a great segue into the next game.The controls are not too difficult to familiarize yourself with, and the tutorial mission is both fun and very helpful - it feels less like a hold-your-hand mission compared to other games that may restrict your actions initially. The learning curve is minimal to moderate, further influenced by the difficulty you select (no notoriety on Rookie) and playstyle you use (stealth vs. bloodshed).Before you begin your missions, you will be able to select which weapons to take with you, as well as upgrade each primary weapon you own - more options are unlocked as you progress. The money you accumulate is based on your rating upon completing your missions (generally, more stealtheir approaches lead to higher rewards). Your performance rating is provided in the form of a newspaper article, with the headline "Silent Assassin" if you achieve a perfect playthrough. I really liked this feature, as it will comment on your most used weapon, firearm accuracy (ex: the 4 headshots and unwasted bullets suggest a deadly professional), number of witnesses and casualties, and how the targets were killed. Each mission has a mechanic available to make each target die in what appears to be an accident (ex: a pallet of crates falling on top of someone), allowing you to achieve full stealth. Notoriety is affected by your performance, and the more attention you draw to yourself, the higher your notoriety gain. As it climbs, NPCs will react faster to your presence and may even call for help from guards. You can pay a fee to reduce your notoriety, and obtaining the CCTV tapes (if you are spotted on camera) will eliminate that hit to your notoriety. My favorite mission involved  assassinating a target in his mansion, while being under the witness protection program. You can deal with the protection detail aggressively - open the doors and unleash a bulletstorm (silenced or not); or, you can even place a posion/sedative into a box of donuts, change into a donutman disguise, and pass the donuts to the security team (eventually causing them to all be knocked out). You can challenge yourself in many ways - try doing a mission without switching into a disguise, being seen (causing an alert), killing, using weapons, etc. I beat Blood Money on the hardest difficulty on my 3rd playthrough (full stealth), and I encourage everyone to NOT try the game on Rookie (the notoriety feature adds a lot of intensity and fun). For my first playthrough, I did full stealth and normal. For my second, I tried a Rambo-style method - both provided me with a satisfying, badass assassin feel. Watching NPCs running away in fear while helpless guards fall to your expertly-placed shots can be just as fulfilling as entering a restricted area without anyone knowing.Overall, the game is very enjoyable if you are the least bit interested in assassinations (stealth or non-stealth), and everyone should definitely give this game a try.Highly recommend!Cheers,DJSF @DJSF's Rogue Reviews

												I can’t even comprehend the amount of times I’ve killed Vinnie “Slugger” Sinistra. In fact, as much as I believed I had killed every target in every way possible, even today I found a new way to eliminate Vinnie. I purchased this game in 2006 originally, and I can’t even imagine how many hours I’ve spent playing it since. It was great picking it up again on steam and going through it all once more and remembering each and every style, technique, path to become the perfect Silent Assassin. Blood Money brings the series back to familiar territory, after the dark path of Contracts (Hitman 3). This is why I rate Blood Money and Silent Assassin as my two favourite in the series, purely due to the vast possibilities of completing missions. For instance today – setting a mine off outside Vinnie’s house and attracting all FBI members outside the building, I ran towards the front door where Vinnie stared right at me, and began chasing me. I led him to the road just outside his front door, knowing full-well that in approximately 5 seconds the FBI *backup* Limo would speed its way to the entrance. So yeah, with Vinnie looking confused and wanting to know who I was – and standing directly in the centre of the road – BANG. Goodnight Vin! So much for that FBI Witness Protection program! It’s hilariously entertaining & ruthless at the same time. What other game can you sedate food dressed as a Clown? Rig a barbeque dressed as the local neighbourhood Pool Cleaner? I am only talking about one mission here (A New Life) there is an outrageous amount of different possibilities to this game and that’s why 9 years on I’m still having fun & enjoying new ways to go through Hitman: Blood Money. An incredible combination of stealth & brutality lets this game shine for many more years to come.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												When people talk Hitman there's usually one game they have in mind and that's Blood Money. Hitman is a series that boasted a novel concept which has somehow managed to remain pretty unique to this day (seriously - how many disguise-based stealth games are there?) and that gameplay evolved from game to game with Blood Money being the pinnacle (since Absolution went in a somewhat different direction closer to other stealth franchises like Splinter Cell).Above all Blood Money is an action adventure game. Each mission provides quite a huge and open area with one ore more targets which need to be assassinated as well as the occasional non-assassination goal. Each map features many characters following basic routines and items or statics objects which can somehow be put to use. The beauty of Hitman lies in exploring the big and diverse environments, discovering usable objects, observing the targets and bystanders and then putting a brilliant plan together - and somewhat ironically the best and toughest plan is always the one where nobody dies, except for the targets of course. It gets even more complicated when you wish to make the deaths look like accidents and leave nothing behind (especially not that precious suit!). But even once you've developed that brilliant plan, there's still the matter of execution which requires perfect timing, with wits, patience and a good memory being the key to success - one mistake and everything goes to hell and there's not much left to do except mowing down everyone in your path.As an action game Hitman is definitely sub-par but if you're up for it and are willing to spend ages on the same mission until you find and execute that perfect plan (or at least one perfect plan as often there's several ways to get that awesome Silent Assassin rating) there's nothing quite like it and a truly rewarding experience awaits you.There's not much going on in terms of story, which is told through non-interactive cutscenes, but that doesn't keep the game from providing many very original locations and missions depicting the criminal underworld from a wide variety of angles, mostly ones you don't know from other games. To top it all off the action is accompanied by one of the greatest soundtracks to be ever heard in a video game, composed by legendary Jesper Kyd, providing a truly surreal atmosphere at times. What kind of graphics to expect everyone can clearly see on the screenshots.Bottom line: if you are looking for an original stealth game or just want to know what all this Hitman talk is about - this is the game to go with.

Posted: February 27, 2014
												Hitman Blood Money is an epitome of the Sandbox genre. This game requires skill and patience with almost endless possibilities to every mission. Not only are you allowed almost infinite options on how you come to face your target, but also how you chose to eliminate them.Blood Money also offers an enjoyable experience to Stealth fans, but with a different approach. A majority of stealth games pride themselves on wall-to-wall, shadow-to-shadow gameplay; and while this can be very enjoyable and exciting; there are different ways to enjoy a stealth style experience; Blood Money is one of them! You are keeping your true identity hidden, not letting the enemy guards notice that their perimeter is breached; not allowing anyone to know you are even there. And when it all goes belly-up it still offers just as an enjoyable time trying to dig your-self out of that mess!Obviously Blood Money has a few dated features like glitchy ragdolls; dated textures and filtering. But when you look past this, you see a game that far surpasses most modern day games in areas specifically such as the plot and level design. But if you are a gamer who when searching for new games mainly looks at the visual side of things, this may not be for you.Blood Money also offers the ability for players to customize certain weapons with features such as silencers, scopes; different ammo types etc. Sadly, not all weapons found throughout the game allow you to do so, but this feature is still only found in very few games; including those of the current high budget new-releases. If I were playing this game at the time it was first released, it would have been a game with no noticeable flaws, but certain dated features cannot be ignored by today’s standards. Although the game’s base design is still without a doubt, impeccable, as are its plots and levels.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2016
												Booted up Hitman: Blood Money two days ago, after having not played it since 2006 or 2007.Just beat it today.Few things I found interesting about it:- It's a 2006 PC port. You can run it at 4k just by making an ini edit, and it's flawless (doesn't break the UI or anything).- As far as tech issues go, there was a bit of stuttering I fixed by going into the launcher and enabling both of the SLI settings (even though I'm not on SLI), but after that, game ran like it was made for my system. Then a lot of newer games have all these compatability issues and such until they're patched... were the people who made this game just better at what they did? Or have engines become so massive and unwieldy that it's more likely that things are going to fail than work? Or a combination of both?- I had no bugs whatsoever.- It has a first-person and third-person view - I know games did it even sooner, but I still think it's weird how a game from 2006 had this feature, and then it was a "big deal" when the GTAV re-release introduced a first-person mode.- obviously the textures and lighting are a bit dated, but the game still looks great. I think it's almost the perfect balance between the awkward 3D years where I couldn't believe any of it was real because it was too ugly, and nowadays where everything that goes for this style is hyper-realistic and immersion breaking because of it. This game is actually better looking to me than a lot of modern games that have that hyper-realistic plastic-surgeon-with-OCD look.- the music is still phenomenal, of course- the game doesn't pester you or tell you explicitly how to do everything. There are a lot of hints on the lower difficulties (on the map), but if you want to play it as a proper stealth game, you have to figure out how all the pieces fit together on their own. It has a lot of space. The game is challenging in its own way, but due to the way it's all set up, it's actually relaxing to play. I'm not being yelled at or expected to be somewhere constantly or being given game information nonstop because the people who made it were afraid that if the game stopped talking to the player for 10 seconds I would shut it off and leave. I can just enjoy it without being nagged and feeling rushed along because of the "look here, do this, look here, shoot this" mentality. It lets you play.- the worst thing about it is some character model pop-in, like the game runs a lower-poly version of them in the distance and when you get close makes them proper (I don't think I would've noticed this during my PS2 playthrough when it was new, but on PC at high-res and everything cranked it's pretty obvious)- To boot every level is its own theme. If any copy-paste is going on it's minimal. There's more variety in the levels in a five hour game than I even saw in DOOM. Blood Money is genuinely interesting to play and anyone who hasn't played it yet needs to get it over with and understand why most people rant about most games. Once you have the best of everything, there's just a bunch of s*** you wade through hoping to find another game like Blood Money.- Probably the best thing about it - it doesn't overstay its welcome. I played it on Expert (hadn't played in a loooong time so why would I Pro?), and beat every level with a Ghost, Professional or Silent Assassin rating, in just over 5 hours. I did remember some of the levels, but for the most part, I was blind here. It's refreshing, because they could've gone longer, they could've recycled assets to stretch it out, but why? Why do games need to last "forever"?I did reinstall Absolution out of curiosity.  I ran it at max settings except for FXAA (which only blurs the image).  Even though the tech Absolution uses is way better, and the textures are obviously much higher res, the game isn't as nice to look at as Blood Money. Tech isn't everything. But when you don't know how to make a good game (something that I think needs to be a natural talent, like writing a good song or a good script - a few people have it, most people don't), you can at least learn how to push tech.  And I think those are the majority of people making games these days, which is why going back to Blood Money is... holy♥♥♥♥♥♥.. most games really *are* as bad as I think they are.But Blood Money is a masterpiece.

												The best Hitman game ever made and by far one of the best Stealth Assassin games ever made.Pros & Features:This is a game that lets play with a number of playstyles. If you play like a pro you'll play Silent Assassin difficulty and never be satisfied until you have a Silent Assassin ranking on all missions, which rewards you with the most cash and the highest rating. You can blend in with crowds, disguise yourself as NPC's and watch NPC behavior, using a wide variety of methods to assassinate your targets. You can even make deaths look like accidents on most levels.Alternately you can murder anyone you want, or everyone if you really want a massacre in the newspaper. Yes, at the end of each mission you get a newspaper report that mentions the number of people found dead, the number of witnesses, whether or not there were signs of a professional assassination, and whether or not deaths are believed to be natural or accidents rather than assasinations. In addition to being a professional assassin you can collect weapons from missions, adding an element of replayability, additionally you can upgrade your own weapons and gear with cash you collect from missions.The game has gamepad support and works great with mouse and keyboard, it's well worth purchasing.It's a damn shame that there has never been another game like Hitman Blood Money.Cons & Drawbacks:The controls are rather clunky at times, in a way that adds to the stealth focus but it also just feels and looks clunky sometimes.The graphics are a bit dated. Still passible but dated.The voice acting is sometimes hilariously bad, that may be intentional though as there is a lot of dark humor.

Posted: January 30, 2014
												To me this is the easiest game in the Hitman franchise, but it's also one of the best! The amount of varied missions here and the numerous ways to complete them result in endless replayability. I must have played 50,000+ hours on my retail copy, and I still find myself coming back to this game and finding new things I didn't notice before. Honestly there's not one mission I hate in this game, and each one is a nice sandbox-type map where you are thrown in and told to kill somebody; how you do that is up to you.If you're new to the series I would suggest buying this game first and avoiding the mess that was "Absolution" altogether; or wait until it's extremely cheap. Blood Money was a near perfect game and should have been the standard that all future Hitman games followed. Instead of Blood Money 2.0 we got a ridiculous wall-hugging game--which might be alright in other games but for Hitman it's awful. Blood Money is not without it's flaws, though. The guards are way too gullible to manipulation; but man is it fun to trick them. They will follow blood trails, pick up dropped weapons, and respond to noises. At the time I had never seen AI this advanced before.Bottomline: the amount of detail and things you can do in this game is amazing. If you've always wanted to play a game that provided hours of replayability as a hitman in a sandbox environment then get this game! The other games in the Hitman series are also fantastic, except for Absolution.

Posted: September 18, 2015
												The highlight of the series, being immensely open-ended with a ton of different options for taking down your target, while having a better coat of polish than the other highlight, Silent Assassin. It's relatively easy to beat the game, but the fun comes from experimenting and figuring out just the many, many ways of finishing each mission, and working towards perfection in your final rating. It's not just a question of stealth versus frontal assault, it's poison versus bomb, sniper rifle versus falling chandelier, rigged fireworks versus chloroformed panties. It's got a dark, noiry style without the grindhouse cheese of Absolution, taking itself seriously even while it lets you do ridiculous things. Even now, having played through more than once, I find myself wanting to go back to try to screw around and finish the missions in new ways or perfect my old plans. I sincerely hope the new Hitman game can even come close to capturing the fun to be had here.

Posted: July 25, 2016
												Hitman: Blood Money is easily the best game in the series. And can easily be considered one of the greatest stealth games ever devised.The reasons are numerous. Hitman Blood Money is a radical improvement over all of the previous games in the series. Taking elements that worked well from each of the previous games, and putting them in a single package. Coupled with numerous additions. Hits can now be completed by making the act resemble an accident, which typically is required to achieve a Silent Assassin rating. Additionally, after each hit you can view a newspaper which documents in detail what you did during the mission and even includes an artists rendering if you were seen by a witness. But that wasn't all. Hitman Blood Money was ahead of it's time in a lot of regards. Much like the previous games you could practice your weapons in 47's hideout. Along with collecting weapons in missions that you could use in other ones. But you could also upgrade your weapons with things like different stocks, magazines and silencers. Normal today but relatively unheard of at the time outside of uber tactical games. One flaw the previous Hitman games would occasionally have is missions would get a little samey after a while. They'd occasionally blend in together with a similar theme. Almost every mission in Hitman Blood Money is distinct, from an opera house hit to a mission taking place on a mississipi river boat. I remembered every single one, and their uniqueness adds a huge amount to how superior this game feels over the previous entries in the series. It really feels special and like the developers worked extremely hard on every single mission. It is just the quintessential Hitman game, technically flawless and masterfully polished. If every series had its own "Blood Money", we wouldn't need sequels.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2015
												Hitman: Blood Money is generally regarded as the best game in the series and definitely lives up to its reputation. Previous games had been plagued by bugs, poor design decisions, and overall unfair situations. This time around, the developers seem to have taken note of what went wrong with previous installations of the series and as a result they have produced a highly polished and well executed hitman game. As per the Hitman formula, most missions require a few trial runs to learn all the necessary elements such as guard positions, entry points, and target vulnerabilities required to perform the necessary executions with maximum efficiency and stealth. In order to get the best rating, it is almost mandatory to study each level in depth to see where your targets will be at their weakest.One thing I noticed with this installment of the series is the introduction of well-handled crowd elements. This feature really shines in the “Murder of Crows” mission where you have to wade through crowds of revelers during Mardi Gras in order to track and eliminate several targets. Other new entries to the series include notoriety which can increase upon being spotted (yellow) or from CCTV sightings, which can be rectified through securing security tapes. There is also the addition of a new execution technique (strangulation) that can be done via elevator hatch above a target.The only downside to this game, and this seems to be a trend for what it’s worth, is the final mission. All of a sudden, despite having done a majority of the game almost entirely in stealth, you are required to gun down an entire area full of trigger happy NPCs. I found it to be entirely inappropriate to the overall storyline not to mention my preferred style of play (silent assassin). Nevertheless, I managed to find a way to take a human shield and plow through the finale. If it were not for that final mission, I would consider Blood Money to be a perfect game. Regardless, it still lives up to its reputation and will likely live on to be the best that Hitman has to offer. Good Luck, 47

												Hitman: Blood Money is pretty cool, I guess.You play as Agent 47, a genetically engineered super assassin created solely to take out the trash. And by trash, I mean murder. The game takes place through various points in Agent 47's life, going from location to location and drowning as many people in their toilets as physically possible. While all this is going on, a reporter is getting a story on Agent 47 from a mysterious man describes his toilet-drowning life. The game is a stealth game but not like you'd suspect. You don't hide in the shadows or repeat the last persons sentence in the form of a question. Instead you're out in the open, blending into society the best way a man can with a barcode on the back of his big beautiful bald head. Get use to it, because you're gonna be staring at it for awhile, not just because you can play the game in third person, but because it's beautiful. I mean, look at it, it's so shiny. Each mission you are given the task of murdering someone who probably has it coming, you do this by planning out an attack, playing dress up like I used to with Polly Pocket because my mom refused to buy me any G.I. Joes because they would encourage  meto be a strong male role model for children. Thanks mom. Now, with the right equipment and the perfect shade of underwear, you go on the attack, soloing out people at their most vulernable and promptly drowning them in a toilet. Way to go! You'd think that this whole murder shtick would get boring after awhile considering it's all you do, but surprise! It doesn't. THe new locations, difficulty of your target, and unique ways you end up drowning others in toilets keeps the game fresh. It's by no means an easy game, unless you're me. Then it's super easy because you're super good and I have a history of drowning others in toilets.Keep that last bit to yourself.But when drowning others in toilets isn't an option or you're just a complete chump, the game gives you a plethora of weapons to go on a murderous rampage with. These include Agent 47's iconic handguns, the silver ballers. They are baller. See what I did there?  While the shooting is nothing special, the guns have just enough OOMF to be entertaining to fire, especially when you send people out doing back flips with hand gun bullets. But surely there's a punishment for going crazy, right? There is, and it digs deep. Not only will the game detract money you can use on new weapons and upgrades, it will also call you a total loser. After each hit, you get a newspaper describing the incident where you're called anything from a Silent Assassins, to a ghost, to a skulking man who drowns people in toilets. The more damage you do and the less inconspicuous you are, the less money you have to spend on yourself. So no new Xbox for poor Agent 47, you horrible person. But should you play Hitman: Blood Money?I will admit, this is probably the last Hitman game you'll play that feels like an honest Hitman game. While it does seem odd for an angry looking man in a bird suit to not look suspicious, the disguise mechanics is what gave the game that flavor it needed to stand out from its competitors like Thief or Splinter Cell. It's fun, it makes you feel like a badass when you succesfully pull off the perfect hit, and it's easy to look over it's problems just by how fun the game is on it's own.Punchman: Booboo Tokens gets 16 corpses in bathrooms out of a possible 4. When hippos are upset, they sweat red. The Curator: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/Dickbuttexperience#curation

												Easily the best Hitman game AS A WHOLE. No online DRM, no bullshit "episodic" DLC, runs smoothly on every computer.With endless replayability and a strangely good blend of solid story and more than a couple broken gameplay mechanics.The only serious problem I have with the game is that the highest terror rating in the newspaper is only terrorist, even if you kill 500 people. That, and the fact that the crowd AI people don't count as kills (the police actually shoot right through them to shoot you, the AI is just that realistic).The AI is pretty much garbage, probably even in 2006 but it all works out because it's actually not that much worse than quite a few other modern titles. What it lacks isn't really important so it doesn't interfere much in gameplay while still remaining hilarious. The only reason Absolution was looked down upon so much was because it lacked many features Blood Money had to begin with like open levels, upgrades on weapons (during the game, a couple levels in Absolution you start off with a crappy revolver [as in no silenced silverballers], which is only really bad because it's unsilenced), Agent 47 not acting like a normal human for the entire story, and a soundtrack somehow worse than Blood Money (which to be fair has a couple of pretty nice soundtracks). There's a good reason everyone was/is so hyped for Hitman 6, as it constantly promised to return to form like Blood Money. Aside from that, Absolution was far from the terrible/"not a Hitman game" it had the rep. for, it just was different enough from Blood Money to get (rather unwarranted) hate for.edit: I forgot to mention throughout the entire game you find hilarious retarded shit like how on Show on the Mississippi River if you shoot the hamburgers in the kitchen blood sprays all over and how if you shoot the First Lady's dog in Amendment XXV half of the time nobody cares the other half they have a grieving animation and voiceline for 5 seconds then move on while the dog's body stays there for the rest of the game.

												The 4th entry into the Hitman series and probably the one that got the most thing right. Whilst Hitman has a new style in Hitman: Absolution, Hitman: Blood Money gives you everything you ever wanted in a Hitman game.Whilst the story of Hitman is good and has many ties to the older games, mostly all the fun comes from the users ability to come up with ways to complete a mission. Do you go all guns blazing, do you shoot the target from after or sneak up close and credit his final breath to the contract. Many missions in the game are iconic and some of the best levels of any Hitman game and present in this edition. Doing hits perfectly in the older games never felt that rewards unless you just wanted to see some text saying "Silent Assassin" or "Ghost" but the developers had a great idea to add a simple yet effective Newspaper system, that would change depending on the style of killing you did, how many people you killed, were you noticed? Did Cameras notice you? Or were you like a Ghost and the Police have no leads? This wil also blend with with notoriety level, this would increase the less careful you were, to the point that Police and body guards might notice you faster and easier if your notoriety is higher than normal adding another dynamic to the game.The graphics for a PS2 era game i thought were very impressive. Hitman himself looks fine, the guns and level designs are what take the show however, some great architecture and wonderful attention to detail in parts of the maps making fun levels better and more immersive. Overall this is one of the great games of it type and in my opinion, the best Hitman game.8.5/10Pro's:- If you like the older games, this is more of the best- New gameplay features stand out to the rest of the series- Array of Guns and Gadgets to knife, blow up or strangle your targets- Great levels with many great levels and few irritating level (Murder of the Crows im looking at you)Con's:- If you are new, some of the levels and learning curve can be complicated- The AI can be easily exploited- Whilst you can play the game the way you want, it can feel like you're been force to be a Silent Assassin unless you don't mind the concequences of just going guns blazing.

Posted: June 14, 2016
												This game is the reason I couldn't really like Hitman: Absolution. I propose my thesis: this game is really fricking awesome.Exhibit A: there is a level that is just you in your hideout. You are not some kind of traveling salesman hitman, peddling your stabby-shooty wares door to door in a car you probably stole from a developmentally disabled man. You have your own little underground hideaway where you can try out your sniper rifle on pop bottles, tell your pet canary he is a pretty bird, murder rats, and sing Ave Maria without the menu screen music reminding you of your tin ear.Exhibit B: Diana! I mentioned in my Absolution review that Diana failed to live up to my expectations in that game, so here's why she's better in this. First, she's her own character. She's busy doing her own thing, scheming, organizing, conspiring with the powers that be to create the bizarreness and awesomeness of that final level. She isn't just stealing some girl and then waiting to be horribly murdered on the toilet. Second, she's mysterious. She's always in shadow, you never see her face, you never know what she's planning. I think maybe we were supposed to instantly feel wrong in Absolution where you see her face on her file, but it's just thrown down in a picture on a file in a cutscene while another character is talking, so it doesn't really have much weight. Also, the only time we see her in Absolution she is naked. So there's that. Finally, she's a really good handler. She's calm and detailed and you can tell she and 47 work well together.Exhibit C: the levels are fun and colorful. Absolution was kind of grey and dreary at times with lots of industrial levels in factories or labs, and even when it was somewhere fun like a barber shop or a tiki hotel everything is sun-faded or blown the heck up. In Blood Money the levels are set in abandoned amusement parks, over-the-top stereotypical suburbia, a steamboat paddling down the river. Everything is very distinct and self-contained.Exhibit D: In this game the cutscenes tell one story, a kind of serious one, but because the cutscene world of the two plot-framing doofuses and the level world of the doofus who got murdered by a scantily clad woman at a Christmas part are so very distinct it doesn't feel like the tone is just very confused.I can't really think of any more exhibits at the moment, so here's a list of fun things to do in Blood Money.1) Drop a piano on a bird-lady.2) Throw a cake on the floor, then pick it up again and use it to blend in the kitchen.3) Run around in a bath robe blowing up cook stoves.4) Snipe a dude off a Ferris Wheel.5) Break into the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ White House and upset the First Lady's tiny obnoxious dog.6) Show up to a private wedding dressed as a drunken hillbilly, shove the bride's father into the swamp, and drive off into the everglades on the priest's air boat.7) Shove people off a boat because that's what they get for going on a boat.8) Dress like a sexy pool boy, murder absolutely everyone at a birthday party, almost get away with it, forget about the family dog, and get your squishy bits bitten off as you go to escape.9) Befriend the neighborhood garbage man.10) Leave a bunch of corpses to ride up and down in the casino elevators.11) Strangle people in the bathroom of a playhouse because that's what they get for not supporting Allegiance at the Tony's.12) Run around a parking garage getting shot to death by a jillion cops and dudes in dorky masks.13) AVE MAREEEEEEEEEIIIIIA

												The definitive game in the Hitman series and a gem of the stealth genre. +YOU GET TO BE A HITMAN+Intricate stealth mechanics+Unique disguise system with a wide assortment of interesting, practical, and funny outfits+Trademark Hitman dark humor+Lots of freedom in how you conduct missions and assassinate targets+Large, open, sandbox levels to explore with very interactive environments-A bit glitchy, but nothing game breakingBlood Money is commonly regarded by fans as the pinnacle of the series. Polishing the gameplay set by previous entries, this masterpiece delivers some of the most unique stealth gameplay available. Hitman is the series that pioneered social stealth, the ability to “hide in plain sight”. The disguise system in Blood Money works great and it’s fun to try different disguises to figure out what works best for certain situations. There are so many memorable levels in Blood Money, and I still manage to find new ways to perform assassinations. Levels like A New Life, Curtains Down, and The House of Cards are works of art. In this game, there are many creative ways to dispatch your targets, more so than any other Hitman game. You can rig a piano to fall on someone’s head, you can blow up a photoshoot with some well placed mines while dressed as Santa Claus, you can silently garrote your target while disguised as a birthday clown. Those who played Absolution and are looking for a taste of what the old games were like should look no further than Blood Money. For its current price, this game is a steal. Without a doubt, this is the best stealth game I have ever played.

Posted: September 26, 2014
 Murder 101 ‘Hitman: Blood Money’ is the fourth entry in the iconic Stealth / Strategy RPG Hitman series, and is simply put, the best game of the franchise. Gorgeous visuals, well designed levels, intuitive gameplay and a compelling storyline make this title Agent 47’s defining moment. Campaign: Released by Eidos / IO Interactive in 2007, ‘Blood Money’ puts gamers back in the familiar shoes of Agent 47 – a professional assassin who is both ruthlessly efficient and disarmingly charming at the same time. The campaign details 47’s first foray across the Atlantic, and its 13 missions take you around the world to varying locales and vastly differing settings - from mountain retreats in the Rockies to Opera Houses in Paris, from Casino’s in Las Vegas to Jungle Hideaway’s in Chile. The missions are seamlessly woven into a broader narrative of the FBI’s efforts to connect the dots in a series of high profile assassinations and the surprising twist ending ensures your attention is kept throughout.Graphics | Sound | Gameplay: Graphically, the game is beautiful, with detailed, lush environments, atmospheric sound and some of the best level design seen in modern gaming. Each mission has several objectives that need to be completed – but be aware – there is no handholding here. True to its ‘Hitman’ roots, ‘Blood Money’ drops you into a large open world level with the freedom to accomplish your objectives in any order you see fit, and you are largely left to figure out the best way to get at your targets and escape unnoticed. Every mission, even every target, can be approached in multiple ways limited seemingly only by your imagination – Sniper kills from afar, close up strangulation with Piano Wire, a poisoned beverage to a distracted gory death are but some of the options at your disposal.  Tight and intuitive K&M controls, a broad selection of weapons, tools and distraction items, and upgradable items available for purchase in-between missions round out your toolkit.Flaws: The game also addresses many of the core gameplay issues and complaints of previous installments while at the same time moving the series forward – the inclusion of plentiful in-game save options, much improved AI, ability to play in both 3rd person and first-person views and high replayability make finding fault difficult. If pressed, a few gripes would be some clunky character animations and a close adherence to the Hitman formula making things seem quite familiar to veterans of the series. Overall, ‘Hitman: Blood Money’ is 47’s finest hour – a visually stunning, atmospheric, Stealth / Strategy RPG that puts you in the shoes of the iconic assassin and where you are ultimately limited only by your imagination in finding new ways to eliminate your target. Highly Recommended – Rated (9/10) Want More Recommendations? Click the 'Follow' button on our Curator Page (Link Attached) to get the latest reviews updated directly onto your Activity Feed. YouTube™ Video: Hitman: Blood Money [Game Review] 

			Views: 205		

			My review of "Hitman: Blood Money", the 2006 action stealth game developed by IO Interactive and published by Square Enix.		

Game: Hitman: Blood MoneyGenre: Stealth ActionDeveloper: IO InteractivePublisher: Square EnixCopy supplied by SteamHitman: Blood Money is the 4th game in the Hitman franchise released in 2006, developed by IO Interactive and published by Square Enix. STORYSome has been killing the agents of ICA, and it's your job as Agent 47 to go around the globe trying to find who is behind this conspiracy. And yes, this is as clichéd as it sounds. But you don't come here for the story itself, but for its settings, which are fantastic: you go to Las Vegas, a wedding on the , the White House, an Opera House, a boat on the Mississipi, a Mardi Gras parade in New Orleans... All the 13 levels have fantastic locations that are very memorable, even though the story is incredibly forgettable.GRAPHICSSurprisingly, the game still looks gorgeous after 10 years. And sure, while a couple of textures aren't in HD, the character animations and the post-processing effects show how much care was put into creating this game. I also love how every single level looks and feels different.GAMEPLAYYour goal is very simple: kill the designated targets as stealthly as possible and leave the area unnoticed. You are free to choose which playstyle to use: equip an assault rifle and go on a loud killing-spree, find a vantage point and snipe from afar, go upclose and personal to garrote them, or, even better, make it look like an accident.The best example of this is the Curtains Down mission: you are at the theatre during the rehersal of Puccini's classic opera "Tosca", and one of the two targets is playing the lead role, who gets executed with a pistol. In order to make it all look like an accident, you can switch the prop gun with a real WWI handgun. You can guess what happens next.This is just one of many things that makes Blood Money a fantastic game to just play around with and to experiment to get different outcomes. There are also other details, like being able to carry only one heavy weapon (shotgun, assault and sniper rifle) that can't be stored in your suit since it's too big. There are also upgrades to buy before each level to reduce recoil, improve damage or get silencers.And, in case you didn't know, by pressing F1 you can enter First-Person mode to improve your shooting. I didn't know this when I first played the game, but it sure helps if you get into some tough gunfights.CHALLENGEThe AI makes the game very challenging: they hear gunshots, they recognise you based on the outfit you are wearing, they follow blood trails and they change how they react based on who dies. And, in case you get seen, you can try to shoot your way out of it, even though going full-on stealth is the best way to play this. Also, there is a save system that can be used in each level to correct some mistakes and to try without fear certain playstyles.SOUNDThe sound effects are top notch, as well as the voice acting, and the soundtrack by Jesper Kyd is beautiful, from the Main Theme to Apocalypse, as well as Ave Maria by Schubert.REPLAYABILITYMultiple ways to kill your enemies, easter eggs and secrets will keep you coming back to this game for years to come.Overall, this is easily one of the best stealth games of all time thanks to the variety of levels, weapons and excellent AI. A must play for every gamer and stealth fan.Story: 7.5Graphics: 8.5Gameplay: 9.5Challenge: 9Sound: 10Replayability: 9ENJOYMENT: 9FRUSTRATION: 6Follow me on Twitter: @nickygra97Subscribe to my channelLike on FacebookJoin my Steam group

content:
Posted: March 19, 2014
												Blood Money is the 4th game in the Hitman franchise - released in 2006, 6 years before the next episode reached completion in development. It took IO Interactive quite a long time to develop the latest episode for the game industry's (probably) most famous assassin. As to what caused this postponement I do not know - perhaps the reception of Blood Money had been negative or somewhat mixed. My feelings about the game are only positive and I salute IO for making such an amazing, stealth-based action-adventure software that offers high replayability due to the various difficulty settings available.Blood Money gives us a different setting in each mission. Hitman eliminates a gang on a riverboat in Mississippi, approaches a drug lord in Chile, takes down members of a rivaling organisation during a street festival, eliminates a sheikh in a casino in Vegas and more! Every level is very different from its predecessor - it requires different tactics and it is very important to pay attention to your surroundings, i.e. where the enemies are, what their patrolling route is, what disguises you need for them not to be able to recognise you etc. Attention to detail is top notch. The game looks good, runs well and has very decent voice acting. Music was composed by Jesper Kyd who later on presented us with the excellent score of Assassins Creed.More than one solution exists to solve a mission. The game, therefore, is varied and offers replayability as some solutions require more finesse and while they offer you the easy way out (i.e. no violent encounters) the execution can hold you for hours. In fact, a higher difficulty setting allows you only to save fewer times so you really need to plan every move carefully. Higher difficulty levels yield you with extra money after the mission as the game offers no achievements. More money means better weapons and gadgets at your disposal. But if you prefer the stealth approach you will not purchase new weapons or upgrade your existing ones with the extra sum - you, instead, will use this to bribe key people to decrease your notoriety. Also, when you play the game for the first time, it is advisable to purchase information; information that helps you with the solution in each mission in the form of tips, personal messages.In Hitman you need to obtain a disguise all the time to get past certain points in the level. While stealth-based games are many I do not recall any of these out there offering this option. In many cases you need to use more than one disguise and just to make the game more challenging you get extra money for reaching the extraction point in your tuxedo, how you originally started your mission. Even the story is interesting and has some surprises - just to mention the name of some locations towards the end of it would be a spoiler so you can find it out for yourselves.Blood Money is an exceptionally good game. Absolution is the "next-gen" version of Hitman - but if you don't mind playing a challenging and exciting game that is 6 years old Blood Money is for you.

Posted: June 21, 2015
												This game is like a puzzle rather than a straight out-and-out murder simulator. You plan your hit as you go, take note of points of interest, then attempt to execute the plan in as tight a timing as you can manage with as literal collateral and evidence possible. Get in, subdue the guards, strangle the target to death, then plant the barbell over his neck so it seems like he died when working out. Why did the guards get KO'd? They won't know, or care.But on your way out of the room containing the dead target and his unconscious guards, you're spotted by an obese, elderly southern woman who starts screaming bloody murder, waving her arms and stomping her feet like it's the running of the bald, and suddenly you're in a hardcore chase simulator where you -have- to catch up to the tubbo and snap her neck before tossing her over a railing lest she lose you the coveted Silent Assassin rating.As you manage to pull a kitchen knife -- wait, a kitchen knife? Right. You picked up a kitchen knife for the melee unlock at the end of the level.. only you remember that's only in Contracts. Either way, you pull out a kitchen knife by mistake instead of the fibre wire, and you end up slitting the poor woman's throat and watching her slowly tumble to her knees and cover the walls in her ragu as you contemplate what a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ you are.As this happens, you realize the clown and the caterer have seen the entire chase and murderer, and are now making their way to the Secret Service van positioned outside to keep an eye on the witness you were dispatched to.. dispatch. Pulling your pistol out of your coat, you put a round into the backs of their heads with expert precision and wipe sweat from your shiny bald plate as you manage to sprint to the exit before the guards can find the brutal murder-trail you've left behind.At the ending stats screen you realize that you left your suit and a customized gun behind alongside killing three innocents, so you don't get a Silent Assassin rating and have to spend a whole chunk of your assassination fee to clean up after the ♥♥♥♥ing carnage you've caused.And that's Hitman: Blood Money. And it is fantastic.

												If you're looking for an assassination sim, then this is THE game to play.For starters, the game gives you practically limitless freedom in every mission (except in the final mission of course, but no one likes that mission) and the game has tons of variety from mission to mission, in terms of both settings and the enviromental kills you can use. The sheer size of the levels will complete overwhelm you intially; making success seem almost impossible. But through countless restarts, you'll slowly piece together a plan to kill your targets in the most effective way possible, making the game feel like a puzzle game at times. What's more, the levels are highly replayable thanks to a scoring system that encourages you to be as discreet as possible; meaning you'll have a few late nights trying to get the highest rank on a particular mission- and it's extremely fun to do.Other than having a linear tutorial and the aforementioned awful final mission, this game has very few flaws. It also runs well on mediocre gaming PCs, which is also a plus.Overall, if games like Assassin's Creed are a little to "loud" for your liking, then this is the game for you.

content:
Posted: August 8, 2016
												Hitman: Blood MoneyI remember playing this game a long time ago and having a blast. Revisting it on Steam was very much worth it.Positives:+ Agent 47 now has more choices than ever when taking out a target. This game is awesome, and leaps ahead of its predecessors. Each assassination has many, many different ways to be pursued, a lot more than Contracts, Silent Assassin or Codename 47. Feel like staging an accident at an opera? Head backstage and swap the prop gun for a real one, then blow the chandelier foundations up with explosives, so they drop on your 2nd target. How about taking out a target in FBI witness protection? The target is having a birthday party for his child, so you can incapacitate a clown and walk right through the front doors. Then slip into the sauna where a spare FBI suit is and strangle your target to death with fiber wire. This is just the tip of the iceberg. So much variety it's amazing - which also means HUGE replayability.+ Graphics are pretty damn good for 2006, they hold up really well for a decade old game.+ Story is cleverly interwovern between the assassination missions, revealing more of the plot as you progress. I found it to be quite interesting.+ Stealth is superb in this game. You're going to need disguises, be it a waiter, garbage man, chef, policeman or whatever is applicable for your plan. Certain areas are restriced to those with access, so you're going to need the right disguises or move silently to avoid guard patrols. Hiding bodies is crucial to success, and for the first time in the series these can be concealed in freezers boxes or long, wooden crates. + How professionally you perform your hits impacts on your notoriety and how much money you earn. Cash can be spent on body armour and health upgrades or modifications for weapons like silencers, scopes and sights.Mixed:~ A lot of Hitman: Blood Money's gameplay revolves around understanding guard patrol patterns, timing and then perfect execution (this is of course if you're trying to achieve the perfect assassination). On the higher difficulties like expert, only 3 saves are permitted each mission and it can actually be quite difficult, until you work out the patterns. This is both good and bad. On one hand, there's too much focus on the previously mentioned mechanics which are time consuming. It can take hours to get the hit just right, with minimal civilian and bodyguard casualties. You'll be reloading endlessly, trying new combinations or methods to find what works best. On the other hand, this is part of the reason the game shines - to be the best assassin you have to perform like the best assassin. You need to think ahead and be on top of your game. It's a double-edged sword.Negatives:- Controls are a bit awkward, takes time to get used to. Could have been more polished for sure, but it's just a matter of adaptation. Overall Score: 9/10Conclusion: Best Hitman game of the series. It has style, great visuals, smart level design and solid storytelling. Don't miss out on this game, it's only a few dollars on sale.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												This is the first Hitman game i've ever played, and i liked it more than i thought i would. It's essentially a puzzle game set inside real-world sandboxes - you walk around in plain sight trying to figure out how to best distract or impersonate the guards to get to your target and then get back out again. It is very refreshing to play a game that has a true-to-life amount of civilians walking around in it instead of being stuck in abandoned city blocks or enemy bases. Of course, if you start attacking those civilians indiscriminately, you will be dead in no seconds flat. Really cool concept.The unfortunate thing is that the game is designed around trial and error. You have to die over and over to figure out what places you are allowed to go, and to figure out the movements of your targets. You also get limited saves, so eventually it just gets frustrating. It's a testament to the game that even after i started using walkthroughs to figure out where to go without having to repeat sections over and over it was pretty fun. If you are into pure stealth spy games (there are no dialog options/conversation challenges), it's certainly worth the pittance it goes for these days.

content:
Posted: October 3, 2016
												A violent puzzler.Hitman: Bloody Money has you returning as 47, the worlds greatest assassin. The story is told from the perspective of the CIA director, with the missions of 47 having already taken place. While you are performing hits for the agency, there are forces moving against the organization.Each mission is a level, pitting 47 against various levels of security, scrutiny and other challenges. The player can become a 1 man army, killing everyone in sight, or use stealth and assume identities of others, setting up "accidents" and meticulously crafting the perfect kill to obtain the silent assassin ranking. Each mission ends with a newspaper detailing the event, which is a nice touch. The game truly shines by allowing multiple solutions and it's worth while to see how other players pulled off their level clears. The more professional the hit, the more money you earn which goes towards upgrading your tools.I went for professional difficulty, silent assassin ranking for all the missions so I can't speak to much for the gun mechanics. There are a wide variety of weapons and you are able to collect more by placing a newly acquired gun into an ICA boxes. There is an option to go into fps (F1 key) if you want to go in guns a blazing. In 3rd person, the accuracy of weapons seems off at times.Getting away clean is difficult, but rewarding. Silent assassin ranking is achieved by killing only targets (accept for accidents), having no witnesses, and not blowing your cover. On professional difficulty, you cannot leave any items such as custom weapons nor your suit as evidence. You can use undetectable items, such as poison, sedatives, piano wire, and detonators to get past security, or use the environment to sneak weapons through. You can take almost anyone's clothes to gain unrestricted access to different area as you approach your target. Avoiding detection is tricky due to keeping track of so many NPCs and trying to figure out where your new identity allows you access (or doesn't allow access is just as important). Some trial and error is needed to get the feel of the level before you can plan let alone execute your mission.AI was solid for the most part. Sometimes I was frustrated by what seemed to be an overly suspicious NPC or a phantom witness. I watched other solutions to all the missions, and there really are multiple ways to complete them all though there will be some obvious similarities. The graphics do show their age and at times interactions with the environment or your items can be clunky (oh that panic of trying to move a body out of a door way). While some interactions may not seem obvious (like which NPCs you can talk to), there is intelligence available for every mission (for a few around $3,500 each) that will point out there existence. Hitman: Blood Money is a challenging game, but mostly for the right reasons. The level designs with the the allowance for so many possible variations of game play make it an enjoyable experience.

												Hitman: Blood Money...so rage inducing yet you can't stop trying. You need a huge amount of patience for this game. I have patience, but sometimes it can take a very long time to figure out exactly how to do things without getting yourself killed. There are elements in this game that are unmatched even to this day. This is the only franchise where you can change outfits and actually go in disguise freely. You need to watch movements and it's a whole lot of trial and error in every single contract you have. But when you figure it out, it feels so rewarding knowing you had the determination and critical thinking to pull it off. And you can always go back and see if it can be done differently. I only completed the first real level; but I've played enough to judge the game. I think despite some irritating problems, it's a good game and it aged well. And just a side note: If you haven't played Absolution and you're wondering whether or not to get it...yes it's worth the money. All the diehard Hitman fans are just butthurt because the new developers decided to change some things around to try something new. That doesn't make it a bad game. I do however agree that the new stealth system is rather dumb at times since you use energy to hide your face even when you're in disguise. It has more of a Splinter Cell feel for sure; but it still has the Hitman elements we all expect.

												Hitman. The known game franchise where you're put in the role of an assasin and which trademark is using disguise to your advantage. You will visit various locations in Hitman Blood Money and have various scenery on the missions. You go from Piers to Suburbs, to Operas to Las Vegas Casinos to Cemetary to Hideout.. you name it. The objective of the game sounds very simple but the ways to it, vary in how difficult it is to get to the objective, which is.. kill the target :)There are quite many ways usually to complete an objective and that is nice that the player isn't being forced to play it a certain way only but is being given room to experiment with different style approaches. Good examples would be.. You could snipe the target from long range, you could switch a prop blank shooting gun to a real version of it, or you could use the environment to your advantage by forexample dropping a big heavy chandelier light over the target via carefully timed remote-triggering of an explosive. There are many ways to get the job done.Game is fairly long. I finished it in 14,7hrs with a stealthy gameplay approach and I didn't feel like the game ended abruptly but instead was just the right lenght, since I didn't feel like it started dragging nor that it ended too soon but was just perfect lenght. Because the game is now quite old, it is possible to get it cheap even on normal price of 8,99€ and with that price, it is totally worth the ~15hrs it offers.

content:
Posted: March 18
												Hitman: Blood Money is one of my favorite games of all time. It took what was good about the previous entries in the series, improved on their problems while also bringing new features to the table to set it apart from the rest. What we ended up with was a masterpiece, and a game I have had many hours of fun with. The gameplay here is simple: you start on a map with one or several targets to kill, and sometimes some documents or items to recover. It's execution is where it shines, as Blood Money allows you tons of opportunities to complete your objective. For example, there is a mission in the game called Curtains Down. In this mission, you have to kill a french actor and his producer, who are involved in a prostitution ring. You have the option of climbing into the rafters and sniping them, switching out a prop gun with a real one and killing him in front of an audience, switching out the gun and letting the other actor kill your target, blowing up a chandelier and having it drop on the producer, etc. There are so many ways to kill these targets, and I'm sure I haven't found them all. There are 12 levels in the game in total, and they all are very unique. Unlike the last game, which was very repetitive, this game has levels set in a Vegas Casino, Mardi Gras, a French Theater, a River Steam Boat, a standard house used by Witness Protection, and many more. Every level feels unique, thanks to great level design and good atmosphere. The npc's will speak with an accent or in other languages, depending on where the level is set, which really helps with immersion. The main focus of the gameplay is replayablility, and this game does it better than any other Hitman game. Every level has several opportunities for creative kills, and finding them all always kept me coming back for more. As far as the story goes, it's weak like every other Hitman game, but the story is not why you should play this game. This game does have a few flaws, but not enough to ruin my enjoyment. For instance, the ragdolls are very stiff, like the other games. After you kill someone, their body will re-straighten itself, which is a bit immersion breaking unless you push someone to their death so you no longer see the body, or use fiber wire which would normally result in a straighter body. Another issue is that you can't aim with a gun, which makes the gunplay less fun. If you want to kill someone with a gun, you have to put the crosshair on them, and the gun will automatically come up and go down when you fire. This is a shame for me since I love the blood effects in this game. A lot of detail was used in the cloud, wall stain and pooling effects but it's not as fun when you can't aim and you end up with a straight ragdoll. Other than that, this game is near perfect. $8.99 is too cheap of a price so unless a sale is right around the corner, buy it now at full price! If they charged $20 I would have gotten my money's worth, so I'm glad it's less. This game is awesome and I think everyone should play it.

content:
Posted: February 12
												You are Agent 47, a bald assassin. Your job? Professional assassination. Your methods? Entirely up to you, and that's where the game shines. Whether it's infiltrating the house of a mobster-turned-informant dressed as a birthday clown, sniping a Chilean drug lord as he looks out from his balcony over a waterfall, shooting out the bottom of a pool suspended over a colossal drop and watching a son whose sexual exploits risk damaging his father's political campaign fall hundreds of metres to his death or assaulting a costume party with an SMG and dual pistols, the amount of freedom this game gives you is insane. All of your equipment can be upgraded and improved via an upgrade system that perfectly rewards you for playing well. The less of a mess you cause - ideally, you kill only your target, do it with an 'accident' and leave the area in the suit you arrived in - the more money you are awarded at the end of a mission. That money can be spent on better lockpicks, larger ammunition clips, more effective telescopic sights and so on. Without spoiling anything, the story is nothing to speak of. It ties the game together and the voice acting is decent but it's not Hitman 2. The graphics still hold up extremely well even nearly 11 years after the game first launched, as do the controls and menus. I barely even noticed I was playing something ancient by gaming standards - Hitman: Blood Money feels modern, much more than something like Death to Spies (which you should also totally play) which is around the same age. On top of all that, you can get it on sale for less than £2. But it's totally worth the full price. So scroll up and press buy. You will not regret it.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2014
												The Hitman series has always been known for its mix of stealth and action gameplay, and this entry of the series is no different.The game plot is revealed by a series of interview pieces with a retired police officer, in which he usually tells something about the death of a certain person that most people thought something (a different story to the public) and turns out it was something entirely different involving 47.At first these don't make much sense, but as you play the game, you start to see where the plot is going, there aren't many remarkable points on it with the exception of the ending (which is amazingly delivered), so no spoilers.The gameplay of this game follows the tradition of the old entries of the series, which is a good thing since it is what makes this series unique: you receive a briefing showing the place, who you have to eliminate, the background story of said person/people, then you choose your starting equipment and you are ready to go. What makes the game unique is that you can play in a stealth approach: observing enemy patrols, finding out how to infiltrate certain places, and planning a way to get close enough to take out your target or even how to take them down from afar.One of the main features of the game that is still intact is that 47 is still a master of disguises and has the ability to change his clothing in seconds (it may sound a little weird, but it explains how someone can do the stuff he pulls off), which in most cases is the only way to access certain locations in the game. For instance, only workers can enter a part of the opera house that is still being build, I mean, you can enter without disguise, but that will attract attention AND the guards of the place.An addition made in this game, is that now 47 can move faster while sneaking, in previous games, it was hard and painful to sneak around because it was too slow. He can now throw coins around to lure people to someplace where them and 47 can have a more "personal conversation" or simply use them to lure guards out of posts and such.Although it is a stealth game, it is different from what the conventional stealth games are and play. In here, you don't use the darkness to hide, you use the people and your disguises, you can crouch behind something, but don't expect that to go unnoticed: people react to your actions, and someone sees you sneaking around or behind people, they will react properly.It is weird that people only bother listening to YOUR footsteps. For instance, there's this guard walking with another close to him, he'll do his job normally, then later you take out one of the guards and take his place, the other guard WILL start looking back and perplexed stare at you. These things are a little annoying because it happens only with the player. Since you can't sneak all the time without calling unwanted attention, you have to adapt to survive, and having access to a plethora of ways to approach a place/person is what increases its replay value and makes it unique.Also a new feature is the introduction of Accidents. 47 can now push people off rails, roofs, etc, or he can just knock them out and THEN throw them off such places. This adds even more different ways to complete the assignments. Since the money you earn is determined by your performance in the missions, things as killing innocent people or be seeing doing something suspect all count towards your final rating. If someone saw you, you CAN kill this people as a way to have no witnesses, but the game will not penalize you if you can make it look like an accident, this is a nice addition.You can now also customize your weapons, like putting a silencer in your Baller pistols or SMG, or putting a more precise scope at your rifles. Upgrading equipment is also possible now, such as decreasing the time it takes to lockpick a door or increase the distance of where you must be to detonate your remote bombs.A new possibility now in case things get hairy is the ability to take people as human shields. But besides the obvious purpose it also serves as a way to take someone faster to a certain place. For instance, instead of having to wait till the person is knocked down with the effect of some of your tranquilizer syringes and then drag them somewhere more discreet, you can grab then and "quickly" get them elsewhere and THEN knock then out without worrying with the possibility of someone seeing you.In the graphics department, the game handles very well, its attention to detail is remarkable and every place in the game looks convincing, from a suburban house to a rehabilitation clinic or a Mardi Gras parade.The soundtrack in this game is amazing, it server to set the mood for the missions but also to tell the player of the current situation, if something goes wrong and you're about to get shot by the guards, you'll know before hand because of the song that will start playing. The voice acting is really good, David Bateson delivers a believable cold Agent 47 as always, and Vivienne McKee does a great job bringing the faceless Diana to life in her "cold but sometimes caring" voice. The NPC's voices sometimes are goofy and funny but noticeable intended as a way to ease the tension in the game.The big arsenal of weapons, equipments, and disguises give the player a lot of freedom to approach the missions. Being stealthy and infiltrating a place from the back or even the front, or simply go guns blazing, be certain that you can always surprise yourself when things DO work even when you try to be more creative.

												Hitmang: Blood Money is the beautifully crafted story of an adolescent boy growing up trying to figure out what life is all about. In the game you encounter unique moments that are iconic to a young man's life - ranging from killing your first victim to hiding your first cold, lifeless body. Hitmane: Blood Monet is a great game, but it does have it's cons:-Controls are sort of funky -Optimization for PC is just not there-Very violent for an E+ rated game (this really surprised me)-Levels feel very boxed in, and it often feels like there is nowhere to go, and going about most situations is very one-sided.Other than that, the game is sure to provide some quality entertainment. Now for some pros.+Physics engine is pretty good. It can be a bit too realitic sometimes, but that's ok+Graphics are fantastic, especially for when the game was released. They may not be up to par today, but the game is still just as enjoyable.+The story is very rich with drama, romance, comedy, and especially blood - which is just essential for any Hotman game.+Has an E+ rating, so many different types of age groups can enjoy it.Overall, Hit and Run: Brood Mother is a pretty great game! I give it a 9.5/10. Thanks for reading!

Hitman: Blood Money Brief ReviewHitman series is well known for bringing the feeling of being a professional hired assassin to a whole new level. I would say that Hitman: Blood Money is arguably the best game in the Hitman series, but more on that later on.The story revolves around Agent 47, a cloned assassin-for-hire whose flawless record places him in high demand among the wealthy and elite. You don't know much about him or his past. Only thing you are certain of is that he is best in the business. You're thrown into an open world. You're given targets that you must kill and in some instances, objectives to complete. The rest is up to you.Graphics are okay for the time that the game was released and that's the only outdated thing. Gameplay still holds up the fun factor. Stealth can be a little too easy in my opinion, but there are moments that can still be challenging. You choose how you play the game and that's the biggest part of it. If you're thinking of picking this game for the first time beware, you will find yourself spending lots of time doing trial and error to find the best ways to kill your target.If you enjoy a sandbox stealth experience, Hitman: Blood Money is for you. If you enjoy more linear games with story and character progression, avoid it.Should you buy it now, wait for sale or never touch it? Buy it now!

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												This game is by far the best Hitman in the series, even till this day. The playability, even on this platform, is exceptional. No lagging, rendering and most of all no crashing (windows 8). Despite having a lot of options and weapons and ways to use them etc... everything is easy to use after the tutorial mission, nothing too complex. The graphics are awesome, especially taking into account that this game was released over 8 years ago! Hours of fun is to be had with this game, it's entertaining to go and play the game back to do things a little different and see which route to take is the most rewarding one. The introduction of new systems in the series such as a cash system, notoriety system and conventionally a rating system. Each one tying everything in the game together, demontrating why your approach has earned you your reputation/money whether good or bad. Axiomatically the stealth route is the most fruitful, but to blast your way through the game and become notorious can be extremely fun too. There are 13 immersive and addicting levels in the game, each taking around 30-60 minutes to complete, so you will certainly have hours of fun. Each level is beautifully designed and shrewdly thought out, making Agent 47's world one which you will want to go back to again and again. Despite the linear narrative in the game and the ineviable ending, how you get there is what makes this game unique. You notice new things as you go back and play again, noticing different geographical approaches or the fact you completely missed a secure room which takes you on a different route to achieve your assassination(s).The AI need a mention in my review for the vast improvement the developers have made, contrasting previous titles. They are much more intelligent in every sense you can think of when approaching a conventional stealth assassin game. They no longer blow your brains out for wanting to go through a door that is restricted, they just become aware and suspicious of you for wanting to do so. They will ask you to leave, if you do not comply, that's when they logically gun you down. Also, you can no longer hide in the most ridiculous place as the AI will look if they're suspicious of you being in there... for instance, if you shoot from a building and your notoriety shoots up, if you're in a building with a closet and you get in, they will get you out of there... the game prepares you to be more of a stealth killer, or just more prepared for the mini army about to come and get you.  A final mention on the AI is the fact they can see right through your disguise if you do not use them wisely. If you put on a disguise, but have irregular patterns or do suspicious things, their awareness will raise and they'll eventually warn all other staff and before you know it everybody is coming after you. This again engages you to be much more shrewd about your assassination if you take the stealth approach to the game. All in all a beautiful looking and atmospheric game which captivates throughout. The rebuild of the engine has made for great animation with amazing lighting effects and shadows and immaculate detail for a 2006 title. The only negative I can possibly fathom is that the camera can sometimes be a little awkward in tight spaces, such as an elevator, however this takes nothing from the overall playability of the game. It's definitely worth picking up at normal price, but at it's current discounted rate it would be crazy not to!Pros:- Enthralling and story-line that gives many hours to feast upon. - Beautiful scenery in each level and a great atmosphere.- Extremely easy to pick up and play due to it's incredible playability.Cons:- Camera can be awkward at times. Rating: A stolid 9.8 out of 10.
