content:
Posted: January 28, 2014
												I can without hesitation reccomend this game. As of now I have 147 hours of playtime which is probably more than the average person would get out of it. It is not without it's flaws but in my opinion the flaws are not game breaking in the least.Do not be put off by the first mission. The very first mission is a mandatory, linear, and all around just not very fun. It serves to teach you the mechanics without distracting you from the goal. There are other missions just like it which I feel are too linear, but nowhere near as bad as the first. I think this tutorial mission put off too many people who never got to the next one to find how "open" it could be and what the possibilites were like. It's not unbearable but it's so un-indicative of how most of the game goes and what makes it so good.The menu system is pretty clunky. It seems to be really geared toward console gamepad controls. It's a small nitpick and you get used to it quite quickly but it can get annoying if you need to switch items a lot in rapid succession.There is one fault with the rating system I will go into detail about next. There is a way to cause "accidents". You push someone off a cliff/down the stairs/whatever, or maybe you rig something to fall apart or explode suddenly to cause something large to crush them. Now while I love the concept and usually it is brilliant, there are problems. For example, I remember one instance where I wanted to get all accidents for the Silent Ghost rating (the highest paid rating possible). Well, pushing the guy down the stairs was the best way. So I push him and then he falls kind of slowly in what looks like a crawl down the steps. Then what happens? Apparently he didn't "crawl fall" enough and gets up and starts to shoot me along with everyone else. I had to reload and do this many, many times for it to finally work correctly. So I have a little problem with that but it happens relatively few times in the course of a playthrough.So with the things that bother me out of the way, let me lose myself in the seemingly endless things that I love about his game. Starting with the Rating System. Now with this system you are awarded cash and a title depending on many factors including whether you did the optional objectives, how many innocents you knocked out/killed, how many times you alerted guards, how many bodies were found, how many "accidents" occured, what gun was used the most, how many shots hit their target, how accurate you were, noise level, violence level, and a whole bunch of other factors. Most of these come as a straight spreadsheet of info, but some are in the brilliant newspaper front page that you get afterwards. It gives a summary as an article of what you did, whether you silently exectuted the target/s quietly, or went and killed hundreds of people. Seeing the different ratings you can get for accomplishing certain levels of violence, silence, and ways to kill people, really increases replayability and makes certain "runs" pretty fun. Sometimes I just try to see how many people I can kill with a kitchen knife and still finish the mission. Or maybe i'll see how many accidents I can cause.The custom loadout is really well done, but it has one flaw. You are limited in that you can only bring one weapon that you acquired from a mission. Like if you leave a mission with a Mosin Nagant sniper rifle then it becomes available with limited ammo for taking you with you on a mission. But what I don't like is that you can't have 2 rifles, 2 pistols, or 2 sub machine guns. You have 1 pistol, 1 rifle, and 1 submachinegun with no exceptions. I would rather have traded some of the other gadgets i didn't need for more flexibility but it simply wasn't an option. Still, the loadout system is fine despite that limitation. If you're really good then all you need are the syringes and the fiber wire most of the time anyway.The writing is so hilarious. It is mostly self aware of how crappy it is at times and does it for comedic effect. Other times the writing is really witty and feels very real. Mostly everyone fits some sort of stereotype, almost insultingly so, but it has such a charm when a sailor with sideburns on the Mississippi says "Get lost Chum Lee." in a Cajun accent. This game has so much character in the characters if that makes sense. It feels very real, but at the same time it's so very surreal too.The soundtrack is to die for. No really, it's like really well done mostly because of Jesper Kyd when he was, in my opinion, at his peak. It's a very teasy mix of classical and electronic rythums depedning on the mood and what is happening. Easily one of my favorite soundtracks.Another thing I love about this game is the attention to detail. I'm always finding something new. I found out last time I played Curtains Down (a mission in which you are at a french opera house during a practice night). There is a guard constantly "patroling" with a group of people as a tour guide. This guard takes a break and goes into this small closet-like room. When he does you can quickly knock him out/kill him and take his clothes. So when you come back out the group starts following you as if you are the new guide. After a mintue or so of not talking to them they of course disperse sounding agitated in french. It's this kind of nuance and possiblity of discovery that helps me come back to play and see what else I can uncover. I hate to spoil a later mission but for example you walk into a high class party and the singer is absolutely, positively awful. First time I played I didn't even really notice I thought that maybe the game did it for a laugh, but then later you find out that she is the secret assassin there to kill you. That sort of blew my mind when I found out and yet another testament to the small things. You'll notice too that when you kill a contract they will appear in the main menu's chapel sitting in various spots as if attending. I could go on forever about all this little stuff but I think you get it.I can honestly say it's one of my favorite games of all time.  Try it.

												Might be one of the greatest games of all time. I keep coming back to this game every other day.TL;DR You're given a task, complete it by any means necessary or which you see fit. The beauty of Hitman is, you can challange yourself. Challange yourself to never change disguises, challange yourself to hide all bodies, challange yourself to kill all civilians. This is basically postal 2 reimagined as a professional. There are 16 Fully designed levels, which is way more than you get from games such as Battlefield, COD and Modal of Honor. The Hitman series has always been innovative since the beginning and Blood Money now makes it more accessible than before, yet it stills keeps the core of previous titles, only with a little more hints for beginners. Blood Money itself has some standout features, lovely accidents, visually stunning graphics competitive even to this day, a wide variety of customisable and upgradable weapons, and most of all, the all-time assassin classic, hand to hand combat. Due to the fact that it is not focused on story and scripted events, and with the game offering vast number of pathways to achieve your targeted hit makes this title highly re-playable.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												I think at this point most people who know anything about the series have heard that Blood Money is the best. It is. The levels are surprisingly big, for a start. Well, they're not huge compared to say, any shooter, but they're packed full of stuff. Even on my fourth playthrough I still found new things. New ways to kill people, new ways to hide their bodies, etc. It's also very open ended. There's refreshingly little guidance. No annoying helper character telling you which way to go, no big floating arrows, it just puts you in an area with instructions to ruin some poor sod's day and off you go. Yeah there are some optional hints to buy but besides that you're pretty much left to work it out for yourself. This approach does cause some problems, sadly. It means that save scumming is heavily encouraged, as there's a lot you can only work out through experimentation. Often it's not entirely clear which disguises will allow you in which area, but thankfully you're usually allowed to leave the area and find another way in rather than being shot on sight, so that's handy, but it's less forgiving with the actual kills. The NPCs are very unpredictable. It's quite likely that another character will walk in while you're busy killing someone, and there's no way to see it coming or prevent them from spotting you once you've started. Once you have been spotted it's usually easiest to just reload a save. You can try to shoot your way out, but while you can finish the level this way it won't be nearly as satisfying. You can also leg it and put on a different disguise, but a couple of times the guards would shoot me on sight even after doing this. Why? I don't know. This sort of thing can get very frustrating at times, but thankfully the positives of the game outweigh this. Walking into a building, killing your target with little extra damage and walking out again unnoticed is a great feeling. The newspapers at the end of every level add to the sense of acheivement, sure, but they are pretty limited. There's only a couple of things they can say. It'll say what weapon you used, whether you killed anyone besides the target and if there were any witnesses. It'll also criticise your aiming skills every damn time because the guns are just shockingly inaccurate. Even when I was sure I hit every shot it'll still tell me that I missed like 50 of them. I felt insulted.One final note: the notoriety system. The basic idea that you get ranked based on how well you performed the kill and how many witnesses you left is good, but in practice it basically changes nothing. You can just pay to have it reduced, and I could easily afford it every time. It supposedly means that NPCs will be more suspicious of you but as I never actually had any notoriety I don't know how true this is.Despite these issues the game is still great. There are few games that do anything similar. Even the older Hitman games kind of feel more like spy games than assassin games. You'd generally deal with the military rather than being in any public areas, whereas Blood Money offers a wide range of levels in which to be a total ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. There's just nothing else like it and it's a whole lot of fun.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
												Amazing game. Great level design, a good soundtrack, creativity in target execution and an interesting story are most of what made this game really fun for me. As a new player, remember to save a lot (on rookie difficulty) and experiment while loading the save if something goes wrong. Be prepared to spend some time repeating parts of some contracts just to get that silent assassin score, because things won't always go the way you want them to. You learn as you fail, and eventually you get the rewarding silent assassin rating at the end of the mission. This isn't exactly a fast-paced game, so don't buy it expecting it to be one. The gunplay is not really there, because it isn't required if you're attempting to be a silent assassin. You CAN go guns blazing, but the game isn't exactly built around that. Things like how the player is positioned in relation to the camera, make it a bit annoying (if not hard sometimes) to go in and kill everything. That said, you shouldn't really be playing it that way, as there are other games that are meant for fast-paced pew pew action and they do it much better.You definitely do not need any past experience with Hitman games to play this, but there is a learning curve. To those who played Absolution first: This game is nothing like Absolution, it is a completely different genre.10/10, lots of fun and good replay value. Watch some gameplay on youtube (Make sure you don't watch the late-game missions, you might get some spoilers) and decide if this type of game is for you.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2013
												Although I did not expect much of this Hitman iteration, it turned out to be more than just decent. Hitman: Blood Money is by some considered to be 'the better' Hitman game. Although it obviously has an edge over its predecessors as far as graphics and sound effects are concerned, it did a lot of things right.The graphics are decent for its time. While there are definitely some graphics glitches (most ragdoll related), it does not fail to immerse the player. The effects of lighting has been taken advantage of and at this point in the game development industry there's a healthy emphasis on textures except for skyboxes.The gameplay is solid and has only minor glitches that you will likely not even trigger unless you start experimenting. Regardless, none of the glitches you will run into should break the game or your perception of the atmosphere and storyline. And don't get me wrong, it had the potential to go terribly wrong here: the gameplay hooks in on the story and immersion, it could not exist without the storyline, and the storyline would not be convincing without the mechanics this game has to offer. Luckily there's nothing to be afraid of in this regard.The music is fitting and blends the environment and story together. A proper use of sounds and quality voice acting make it the story much more enjoyable. Buy it if you haven't played it yet! Hitman: Blood Money is one of those classics that you should try at least once. It is a good quality game that today's videogame industry should consider looking into as reference material.

												***I don't have much time on the PC version, But combined with the xbox I have well over 100.***I bought Blood Money back in 2007 when I seen it on a shelf at EB games when they still existed for 10 dollars. I knew basically nothing except from what I had seen on a G4 episode of X-Play. I came home, popped it in my white xbox 360, and spent the next few weeks playing this game.Tons of weapons from pistols and rifles to knives and fiber wire, Multiple ways to complete each mission, Great stealth system, All around amazing game. There are 4 difficulty levels that all scale very well. Each difficulty level brings in less help from the agency you work for and more ways to get caught and screw you over in the long run. It's punishing but it does it in a great way. Since you get to play out each mission like you want to, It can lead to great satisfaction when you find new ways to eliminate your target and walk out like nothing happened. From setting it up as a "Incident" to blatently shooting them in the face you can feel like a true assassin to a petty criminal.I don't want to say anything about the story since spoiling anything is never fun.There are minor bugs and glitches with AI and the game enviroment but I have never come across anything game breaking.All in all It's a great game. I recomend picking this game up whenever you have the money to enjoy this cult hit.

content:
Posted: March 16, 2016
												Oh my god, this game is fantastic! This is the first Hitman game I've played completely and the only other one I've played was a few hours of Hitman: Absolution and I found that game to be quite boring so my expectations wasn't that high going into this game but by god, this is one of the best games I've ever played! Everything in this game is just great, great gameplay, fantastic level design, fantastic story, fantastic soundtrack to set the mood and pretty good graphics for a 2006 game to accompany it all.I'm gonna be honest, the tutorial level starts quite dull and is a pretty poor level to show of this fantastic game with but even that has some highlights like the guy you have to assassinate, you actually feel for this guy, yes you feel for someone in a ♥♥♥♥ing tutorial level. But as soon as the tutorial is over then this game goes from good to absolutely unbelievable.For me, what makes this game such a masterpiece is the story and the level design, and these two things are tightly woven together to accompany eachother with cutscenes inbetween each mission that tells a story told from this games villain to a journalist looking for the next big story to report on where the villain talks about all the hits Agent 47 does in this game and the journey the villain and his organisation goes on to try and catch this mythical killer clone. The story is also told from the perspective of Agent 47 and his contracter from the ICA organisation and how they are losing operatives from left to right and how they are being slowly hunted down by someone and the very last level, by god it was absolutely fantastic. Such a great way to end a fantastic game.Did I say that the level design was great? Because it really is, each level in this game lets you approach your target in many different ways so the replayability is up there among the greatest games out there. My favorite missions are the Mardi Gras mission and the last mission before the credits level (Not gonna spoil the setting of that great mission). Before each mission you are able to equip and upgrade different equipment for you to take with you on your mission so if you want to try and take out your target from a distance with a sniper rifle you can do that, if you want to sneak near the target with a uniform you stole from a guard you subdued and take him/her out with your fiber wire or some poison then you can do that as well. Or if you just want to have fun you can spend a ♥♥♥♥ ton of money upgrading your M4 and just gun every single person down. The options are almost infinite but keep in mind that the more professional you are when it comes to taking out your target the more money you will get.The game has a map function built into the game but I highly recommend that you don't use it, it's so fun trying to identify your target through a picture you have in your briefing log and sneaking around the level trying to find where they might be and being able to see where your target is on the map is really really boring in my opinion. The only mission where I'd say it's okay to use the map is on the Hotel mission because that level is huge and there is a total of four different floors where your targets might be so there you can use it because otherwise it would be so frustrating trying to find your target by breaking in to every single hotel room on the level.tl;drPositive:+Fantastic level design+Fantastic story+Fantastic moody soundtrack+Amazing replayability thank to all the different ways you can take out your targets+Great gameplay+Good graphics for a game from 2006Negative:-The AI can be a bit unpredictable and quirky, for some reason I can be spotted directly above the target several floors up

content:
Posted: March 23, 2014
												Pros+Huge amount of freedom in how you take on your assignments. Do you swap a fake gun for a real one, and watch as your target gets killed onstage, or do you snipe him unseen from a balcony? Or do you just rush in with a shotgun and eliminate everybody and anybody? It's your choice!+Graphics are fairly decent for an early 7th gen game, and most systems should run it easily.+Great soundtrack by the legendary Jesper Kyd.+Good voice acting.+Solid game mechanics. Everything, from the disguise system to weapon customizing adds to the game, and doesn't feel like shallow filler.Cons-In game, resolution options are limited, and you may need to edit the .ini files to get one that matches your monitor.-Limited amount of weapons to customize, and all upgrades can be bought fairly quickly.-Not a whole lot of missions (13 total, and 1 is a linear tutorial, and the last one isn't really an assassination, so it's more like 11), but the replay value makes up for it.-Story isn't that interesting, but you can skip the cutscenes at any time, and I don't think people play these games for the story anyway.OverallBeing my first Hitman game, I really enjoyed it. The numerous ways to eliminate your targets and open ended levels add lots of replay value, the game looks nice, and although the story is lacking, it's not awful. Buy it when you have the chance.

												This game is literally a serial killer's sandbox. You have tons of differents ways to kill people, even the newspaper after every mission changes depending on the way you gone about killing your target or targets. The game gives you ranks/money scaled on your performance as a killer. For example, I was called "The Cleaner" for just going straight for the targets and killing them with poison instead of making a mess with guns. I recommend this game for people that like having diversity when it comes to missions/levels in video games, because usually developers fail to add replay ability and it's repetitive. That's not the case for this game. I personally play the mission "Flatline" constantly, simply because it's beautiful environment and different options to see that your targets are dead. This was my childhood game, but I'm not only playing it for its nostalgia. I play it for it's great killing mechanics and it's overall experience. If you buy this game, you will favorite it within minutes.

content:
Posted: February 20, 2015
												Hitman is one of the few stealth games that I can actually sit down and play. I don't play stealth games because of my lack of patience and stealth games are usually pretty linear or bad nowadays, but Hitman is one of the few series that still has some life in it.I remember playing this game first on the Xbox 360, it was the very first game I played on the new machine and was the first 18 game I ever played. I have fond memories of playing this game, so it does hold a dear spot in my heart. But I'm not going to be talking about the Xbox 360 version, or the console game for that matter, I'll be talking about the PC game, which was released on 30th May 2006.I think what you'll notice straight off for the Steam version is that you can't access the internet or chat, or is that just me? I mean, that's pretty damn big, I like to talk to my friends over Steam while I play games, but this game has disabled that, a lot of other games have that problem too, not necessarily with older titles but with newer, indie games too.Hitman Blood Money follows the story of Agent 47, an assassin who arrives in the United States (in this game). Narrated cutscenes drive the story, through the form of an interview, where a journalist interviews a former Director of the FBI. The story spans over the course of two years, the first mission being a-No Spoilers-ish.The graphics, I must say still stand up today in my eyes, but graphics shouldn't turn you off playing a game, that's just stupid. The detail shown on the character models and background is aesthetically pleasing, it always seems to fit the mission perfectly. The missions are all open ended and can be completed in any way you want, ranging from stealth and timing to guns blazing. I went for a stealth option on one mission, which ended up with me stealing a guards clothes, finding a shotgun, garrotting the target, hiding in a closet until the second target came into view, shot him in the face and then ran to a plane as the whole world's military force got nearer to me.This is most certainly the best Hitman game.The game is fun and for £6.99 you're definitely getting your moneys worth.Hitman Blood Money gets an 8/10

content:
Posted: March 15, 2016
												I'm really torn over whether to give this game a positive or negative review. Hitman: Blood Money is an amazing game... one of the best games ever made in my opinion, but it has one massive flaw which I will touch on later. Note that I will give this game a positive review but please, read until the end as depending on your hardware configuration the game may prove itself to be unplayable for you. Let's get it out of the way that the graphics aren't bad - they have a nice style to them - but they aren't the greatest. Lots of noticeable aliasing and the in-game AA drops your framerate immensely. Force AA in your graphics card's control panel... you will get much better results. I could run 32x anti-aliasing with minimal hit through the Nvidia Control Panel, but my frames would halve from 60 to 30 using the in-game maximum of 8x anti-aliasing. If you don't use in-game AA and have a relatively modern computer of any power whether it be a budget laptop or a multi-thousand-dollar gaming PC, you should be able to run this game pretty well due to its' age (not my problem if your PC can't, though - just have to put that out there).The sound is terrific... the sound effects, the positions of sounds, the clarity of everything that's going on, is great. I had it turned up using headphones, and I heard a dog barking in the distance (on the level "A New Life" if anybody's wondering)... I had to mute it and look outside as I legitimately thought it was a real dog barking outside my house.As for the gameplay (which is what really matters), it's a very innovative game with sandbox elements like no other. The story I could care less about; what's awesome is the gameplay. It's not sandbox in the sense that it's open world like in Grand Theft Auto, but in the sense that you get a huge, detailed level with lots of things to do and a million ways to go through with it. If you don't follow a guide, you will have to look long and hard to find someone who played whatever mission by taking the exact same route as you did. Between knocking out guards, using weapons, using the environment around you, spiking drinks, etc., each mission is extremely replayable.  Maybe you're the slip in, lure the target, cap him, and slip out kind of guy. Maybe you prefer to put a little bit of something in that fellow over there's drink so he'll go into the back room to puke his guts out or whatever so you can nab him. Maybe you'd prefer to toss a bomb in the pool and hit the detonator as you're nearing the extraction point to go out with a bang. Maybe you need to go over to the neighbor's house across the street, collect some tranquilizer darts, then go up into the child's treehouse to get his air rifle, use the tranquilizer darts to make the nasty puppy go night-night so you can slip past him, knock out a guard, and take his clothes and go into the building to kill your target pretending you're one of theirs.If you're not interested yet, this game is not for you.Also... if you're an Nvidia owner, this game is not for you unless you like rolling back drivers. Apparently an issue with the newer drivers makes this game crash sometimes on the newspaper screen at the end. Some missions do it, some don't. I shaved my time from 30+ minutes killing and knocking out loads of people down to 3 minutes two clean kills on "A New Life" because it kept crashing at the newspaper screen. I had to switch to my Intel HD 4000 integrated graphics to play that one so it wouldn't crash - and I refuse to roll back drivers as my newer games won't work. Unless you have a dedicated older-games rig or don't mind rolling back drivers, steer clear from this game if you're an Nvidia owner. I can't count how many times I went through that one mission for it to crash at the end, at literally the last screen before you are allowed to hit "Save". If you're an Nvidia owner using more recent drivers and don't mind taking a gamble, it comes pretty cheap and there are Steam refunds after all. If you have an Optimus laptop like I do, just switch it to your HD 4000 - half the framerate but it doesn't crash after you spend all that time trying to finish the mission.

A solid set of missions which take some careful analysis to earn a Silent Assassin rating, with proper suit retrieval and as many new weapons as you can scoop up, but still offer a lot of flexibility in approach. 												It was a dark and cold night, browsing through steam looking at all the different deals with $7 in my wallet and a dusty libary I came across the hitman series in sale, looking through the avaliable purchases I thought to my self, 'Why is hitman: Blood Money rated higher than hitman: Absoloution? surely the newer version should be improved overall?' I decided to first buy absolotuion thinking it would turn out better but after seeing it would take about a day to download I gazed over at blood money and thought why not buy it... When blood money finished downloading and started the game had blown my mind. Hitman: Blood Money is one of the best stealth games I have seen in awhile, better than some next gen games that have recently came out it showed me that age may not always effect the quality of the game. Hitman: Blood Money Cons and Pros Gameplay - 9.5/10+ Disguises works perfectly unlike some other hitman games (Im looking at you Hitman: Absoloution)+ Very large amount of ways to tackle and complete the mission + Variety of melee weapons that can be picked up and used+ Depending on how well you played will effect the final rating of the level and will change the newspaper article and the end of the level which is fun to read ( For example if the player shot a weapon and it missed alot of your targets the newspaper will comment on the skill saying it was of an untrained marksman or such)+ Variety of ways to get rid of a body+ Can kill people or choose to not kill people by sedating them (By people I mean non-targeted people).+ Upgrades to custom weaponary and tools are useful.- Can be very frustrating as some assassinations can be quite difficult - The A.I can start to glitch out when the player is hiding inside a closet. They will sometimes just stand outside the closet or run at it until the player comes out.- Controls are akward in default but you can change them.Graphics 6.5/10- The graphics are dated but not horrible.- Character models lose alot of graphical quality when player is far away, I saw this commonly in the Crow mission.U.I  - 9/10+ Simple Design+ Can choose to go into first person view or third person view at any time.Storyline - 6/10+ Has a good and entertaining ending- There is no real story line aside from 2 characters which talk about the targets you kill in the game and how the police reacted in response.I would recommend this game to someone who is thinking of buying a hitman game but cant choose which one or to someone who enjoys stealth games. worth every single penny.  thanks for reading.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2015
												This is the best Hitman game currently for sale. Obviously some of the controls and gameplay mechanics are a little dated, and the graphics are definitely showing their age, but the level design, options for dealing with each mission, and no-BS mission delivery system are all superb.The levels are huge, freely roamable, and logical. Stealth is rewarded but if you're just trying to finish the game, outright violence works fine, too. As long as you get the job done.Free of the goofy cartoonish personalities and faux-dramatic emotional story of Absolution, Blood Money's story takes a backseat to the actual mechanics of hunting people down and killing them. How you complete the job is up to you, as it should be. Plan your own route, choose your equipment, observe and recon before taking action.The downsides: some of the controls take some getting used to, the AI has some unexpected behaviours (which usually result in them shooting you for some infraction you weren't aware carries the death penalty, such as forgetting to wear a costume to the costume party), and, in my opinion, some of the early-game unmodified weapons are just so poor that they are almost unuseable (the sniper rifle before it is upgraded, for example).Still, if you like games of patience, skill, and outwitting, plus killing people, this is the purest form of Agent 47 currently available.I am looking forward to Hitman 5 this year, which promises to undo many of the mistakes of Absolution, but I'll believe it when I see it.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2015
												If you've never played the Hitman games, get this one. If you have played 'em, but haven't played this one, get this one.Hitman Blood Money is one of those games that people really disliked when it came out, but really pine after years later.It's a strange old game, and there's a few interesting quirks that you'll quickly notice and probably find funny.Let's start with the Gameplay, as that's where HBM really shines. The reason Hitman games are so fun are because of what they require from the player; an inimitable combination of patience, problem solving and timing. HBM is without a doubt the pinnacle of this 'watch, plan, wait, execute' style of gameplay. The infinitely replayable open-ended structure of each of the levels, the scaled timing of each individual NPC's movements and routines, the strange and often unexpected events that randomly catch you off guard and the peculiar brand of dark humour, subtle social satire and movie cliches that fills the game are what make HBM such a classic.My favourite way of playing this game is to enter a level, then explore it, sneak through the restricted areas using disguises or distractions, find the target(s) and watch their every move, plan a way of offing them to make it look like an accident, then casually walk to the escape route whilst nobody's any the wiser to your involvement, and the newspapers that 'review' your performance afterward just list an accident as opposed to a murder or a killing spree.Ah, but i suppose there are a few downsides to the game, and as most players of Hitman know, this comes as no surprise.The physics engine can be (and has always been in any Hitman game) a bit eccentric; There are times that the limbs of K.O. characters flop about uncontrollably if they're being dragged on uneven ground, and occasionally objects clip through parts of the environment in strange and egregious ways. thankfully none of this is game breaking, merely peculiar. The AI can also go a bit screwy on occasion; enemies seeing through disguises can every once in a blue moon happen unexpectedly with no underlying cause, enemies can become suspicious of you even when there's no reason to be, or my favourite, security guys opening fire into a crowd of civilians you're suspected of escaping through (oh, wait.. they do that in the new one too :p).The graphics are nothing to write home about; they were pretty impressive back in 2006, but now they're considered dated and quirky (all the guys have muscles, all the girls have huge implants.. no idea why). HBM should pretty much run on anything of the last 8 or 9 years.. (egad, has it been that long already?)The Audio is pretty good. The soundtrack is very atmospheric, thanks to Jesper Kyd et al. The SFX are pretty standard and the voice acting is nice'n'hammy, which is just what you want from a Hitman game. The Storyline is surprisingly good. There are two seperate narrative strands that meet up right at the end for a climactic finish.To Summarise, if you're the kind of person that wants an immersive, challenging game that involves careful planning, clever distractions and devious, underhanded tactics, then look no further. HBM is a game full of little secrets, subtle jokes and peculiar quirks; it's a game that rewards you for your patience, and lets you play it how you want to. In HBM you can be the Sam Fisher style assassin sneaking in, doing the dirty deed and leaving, or you can be Chow Yun-Fat running in with your dual pistols and fancy suit, capping every bad guy in sight, but you can also be anything in between (as long as you terminate your targets and don't die! :p)-------------Overall: 4/5Audio: 3.5/5Graphics:  3/5Gameplay: 4.5/5

												It's a damn fine game, it has some flaws however.-The controls are a bit derpy at times, so you have to get used to them. -Gameplay wise, you get the option to choose/upgrade weapons, but can basically go around and kill everyone without ever taking out a gun (with a few exceptions to my knowledge). Every mission I've done so far can easily be done without shooting or getting shot, and in most cases if you do get caught, there will be an infinite barrage of guards streaming on your way, so I see the health bar as a joke.-There are many paths you can go by on each mission. There are different difficulties to choose from, but they barely make any difference. The real difficulty is playing the mission without buying any intel, as you will have to think of a tactic, find patterns, and play by trial and error. -There are a few guns to chose from before starting the mission and the only useful one is the pistol, as it is fast, concealable, and is more generally used. The sniper is on the exact other side of the spectrum: The are rarely any circumstances where it is needed. In the first mission, there is one time where I needed a sniper for some punk on a ferris wheel, ended up running right past him because I was a slow sniper. In the opera, I brought a sniper because I thought it would be fun to snipe the guy, and though I was hidden on the balcony on the highest floor, somebody had eagle vision or something and spotted me, wasn't spotted with the pistol.-The AI is alright, nothing special. Most everyone follows a pattern of movement, and there are some peculiar persons to see.I would give it a 7/10; Not for ninjas, not for commandos.

												Hitman: Blood Money will keep you coming back to it's varied levels and the multiple ways to kill your targets. This is a true Hitman game and sticks to the mechanics of it's predecessors (And improves them greatly) The AI is not the smartest, but they suit the game's needs. You can also choose what weapons you want and customize them to your liking. You can run in with your guns out, shooting everything that moves or not use guns at all. It's all up to you and the game won't hold your hand and give you objectives for every single mission. *cough* Absolution *cough* Each mission will require some thinking and planning, but very rewarding I definitely recommend this game over Hitman: Aboslution. Absolution was just too linear and no room to mess around or do things on your own. Hitman: Blood Money is a fantastic game and you should buy it.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2014
												Often called as best Hitman game and for a good reason.Every level is a seperate mission allowing for variety of approaches. The locations are unique and memorable. The targets are interesting with stories of their own. Gameplay wise it is a stardard Hitman affair focusing on getting the right disguise, blending into the crowd and assassinating your target in the least suspicious way. Even though I fully recommend it the game has few issues. In some way it still feels more like a puzzle game than a stealth game. While the brilliant level design allows for many ways of finishing each mission, the game always playes the same way. The "accident" deaths (the best kind of kills score wise) are quite scripted and the game seems to really push you toward using these limited ways of finishing the levels. The guard patrols always follow the same patterns and they are not very reactive. They either discover you and try to kill you (in which case you can restart the mission or shot your way through the level which isn't very fun,) or they ignore you. There is no middle ground, which would complicate things for you but not make it impossible to progress stealthily. Because of that the game almost feels like it has an instant failure state whenever you get discovered. Because of that you will constantly restart missions figuring out the best route for you. Once you figure it out the same route will work just fine every time to play. The missions difficuly falls drastically down as soon as you get a good disguise. While in Hitman 2 a disguise would delay the guard recognizing you, in Blood Money a good disguise will allow you to walk freely throughout the whole mission. Beating a level often comes down to figuring out what is the strongest disguise in the game and getting it as quickly as possible.Writing is dodgy at best. I think the devs were trying to make you now feel bad by killing your targets but jokes and chatter are quite crude. Game would benefit greatly from a better script.Still messing around with levels and trying different approaches and strategies is always fun.

content:
Posted: March 8
												Hitman Blood Money, the fourth game in the Hitman series, and it brings a whole lot more to the table than Hitman Contracts did. Offering a whole new host of options, such as new tools, new outfits, HUGE groups of npcs, and even weapon customization! It also seems like 47 has had a shower since the last game, as he can now walk past a guard without setting off an alarm, and he can even wander around common areas in his suit without being shot. The game also offers a reputation system, wherein the police will actively build a case against you in between levels as you commit crimes and are witnessed by npcs. I think this system works pretty well, but there are irritating little things that bug me about the stealth system. for starters, animals count as witnesses to your crimes, and can raise your notoriety between levels. This carries over to NPCs with "crowd AI" who will not alert the police to your presence...but they will break your suspension meter, making it lock at code yellow until you eliminate the npc  who saw you. so that's annoying.On the reverse side, I quite enjoyed the open freedom to kill my targets, in every way you can think of. from shoving people out the window, to poisoning their beer, to just walking in and blowing them away with a gun. I feel like Hitman Blood Money really strikes the balance between classic Hitman and Hitman Absolution, offering a much better stealth system than the originals, without sacrificing the freedom to wander around the entire map (like other games in the series i may or may be part way through right now)

content:
Posted: March 15, 2016
												I'm really torn over whether to give this game a positive or negative review. Hitman: Blood Money is an amazing game... one of the best games ever made in my opinion, but it has one massive flaw which I will touch on later. Note that I will give this game a positive review but please, read until the end as depending on your hardware configuration the game may prove itself to be unplayable for you. Let's get it out of the way that the graphics aren't bad - they have a nice style to them - but they aren't the greatest. Lots of noticeable aliasing and the in-game AA drops your framerate immensely. Force AA in your graphics card's control panel... you will get much better results. I could run 32x anti-aliasing with minimal hit through the Nvidia Control Panel, but my frames would halve from 60 to 30 using the in-game maximum of 8x anti-aliasing. If you don't use in-game AA and have a relatively modern computer of any power whether it be a budget laptop or a multi-thousand-dollar gaming PC, you should be able to run this game pretty well due to its' age (not my problem if your PC can't, though - just have to put that out there).The sound is terrific... the sound effects, the positions of sounds, the clarity of everything that's going on, is great. I had it turned up using headphones, and I heard a dog barking in the distance (on the level "A New Life" if anybody's wondering)... I had to mute it and look outside as I legitimately thought it was a real dog barking outside my house.As for the gameplay (which is what really matters), it's a very innovative game with sandbox elements like no other. The story I could care less about; what's awesome is the gameplay. It's not sandbox in the sense that it's open world like in Grand Theft Auto, but in the sense that you get a huge, detailed level with lots of things to do and a million ways to go through with it. If you don't follow a guide, you will have to look long and hard to find someone who played whatever mission by taking the exact same route as you did. Between knocking out guards, using weapons, using the environment around you, spiking drinks, etc., each mission is extremely replayable.  Maybe you're the slip in, lure the target, cap him, and slip out kind of guy. Maybe you prefer to put a little bit of something in that fellow over there's drink so he'll go into the back room to puke his guts out or whatever so you can nab him. Maybe you'd prefer to toss a bomb in the pool and hit the detonator as you're nearing the extraction point to go out with a bang. Maybe you need to go over to the neighbor's house across the street, collect some tranquilizer darts, then go up into the child's treehouse to get his air rifle, use the tranquilizer darts to make the nasty puppy go night-night so you can slip past him, knock out a guard, and take his clothes and go into the building to kill your target pretending you're one of theirs.If you're not interested yet, this game is not for you.Also... if you're an Nvidia owner, this game is not for you unless you like rolling back drivers. Apparently an issue with the newer drivers makes this game crash sometimes on the newspaper screen at the end. Some missions do it, some don't. I shaved my time from 30+ minutes killing and knocking out loads of people down to 3 minutes two clean kills on "A New Life" because it kept crashing at the newspaper screen. I had to switch to my Intel HD 4000 integrated graphics to play that one so it wouldn't crash - and I refuse to roll back drivers as my newer games won't work. Unless you have a dedicated older-games rig or don't mind rolling back drivers, steer clear from this game if you're an Nvidia owner. I can't count how many times I went through that one mission for it to crash at the end, at literally the last screen before you are allowed to hit "Save". If you're an Nvidia owner using more recent drivers and don't mind taking a gamble, it comes pretty cheap and there are Steam refunds after all. If you have an Optimus laptop like I do, just switch it to your HD 4000 - half the framerate but it doesn't crash after you spend all that time trying to finish the mission.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2016
												Hitman:Blood Money is one of my favourite games in my entire steam library. It's just so damned good. I've personally never played a hitman game before this one, but because of it I'm probably going to buy more Hitman games. I'm not good at this review thing, but I'll try.H:BM Is a game where you play a bald clone who's job description is "kills people for money." It doesn't matter the requirements, Agent 47 will do them. In other words, you are kind of a badass.Every mission is a new, different experience with new, different people. From sneaking into a wine tasting event to pushing a woman dressed like a devil into a pit of sharks, every level feels different and awesome. The targets you have to kill are all varied, all actual PEOPLE. That being said, that illusion is broken a bit when it comes to the AI, as well as the general look of some of the NPCs. The game has an odd shade to it; the lighting in the game giving a slightly eerie feel to it some times. It also tends to make some NPCs look a bit on the ugly side.  However, that is excusable. It's a game from 2006, and it looks pretty good for that area. That however, is irrelivent. Sometimes, the AI pisses you off because it is all the same, slightly stupid AI. NPCs tend to do dumb things, oft times yelling at you for no reason or just staring at you gormlessly. Everyone stares at you, even while in disguise. The actual annoying part is when NPCs see a dead thing. Like a normal person, they ask: "U k m80?" and then they see the actual death, and go "o snap he ded wat do panic" and run off to get an officer. The problem is, when someone dies, it's buisness as usual a few minutes afterword. But, I suppose common sense vs gameplay mechanics. Everything else about the game is fantastic. The controls are nice, having three different buttons to  perfom actions and select what you wish to do. Some quirks such as Hitman's inability to strangle or knock people out from the front, his apparent love of jumping over all the things, the fact that some rails do not seem to have the ability to have bodies thrown over them, and the magic that is invisible walls that never seem to stop you except when it makes the least sense. I'm looking at you, one weird fence that I can't throw thing's over. However, these are nitpicks, and the actual game is fantastic. You constantly feel ♥♥♥♥ing awesome when you take down the target, and even when you do play the game like Ground Hog Day and abuse saves, you still feel like you've accomplished something. Every level is an intricate clockwork of amazing level design, and there is always one weakness in the security. and finding those weaknesses or seeing opportunities or even devising your own crazy plan that works in the end (With a couple hitches) is a fantastic feeling.Plus, Diana is pretty cool.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2016
												Hitman:Blood Money is one of my favourite games in my entire steam library. It's just so damned good. I've personally never played a hitman game before this one, but because of it I'm probably going to buy more Hitman games. I'm not good at this review thing, but I'll try.H:BM Is a game where you play a bald clone who's job description is "kills people for money." It doesn't matter the requirements, Agent 47 will do them. In other words, you are kind of a badass.Every mission is a new, different experience with new, different people. From sneaking into a wine tasting event to pushing a woman dressed like a devil into a pit of sharks, every level feels different and awesome. The targets you have to kill are all varied, all actual PEOPLE. That being said, that illusion is broken a bit when it comes to the AI, as well as the general look of some of the NPCs. The game has an odd shade to it; the lighting in the game giving a slightly eerie feel to it some times. It also tends to make some NPCs look a bit on the ugly side.  However, that is excusable. It's a game from 2006, and it looks pretty good for that area. That however, is irrelivent. Sometimes, the AI pisses you off because it is all the same, slightly stupid AI. NPCs tend to do dumb things, oft times yelling at you for no reason or just staring at you gormlessly. Everyone stares at you, even while in disguise. The actual annoying part is when NPCs see a dead thing. Like a normal person, they ask: "U k m80?" and then they see the actual death, and go "o snap he ded wat do panic" and run off to get an officer. The problem is, when someone dies, it's buisness as usual a few minutes afterword. But, I suppose common sense vs gameplay mechanics. Everything else about the game is fantastic. The controls are nice, having three different buttons to  perfom actions and select what you wish to do. Some quirks such as Hitman's inability to strangle or knock people out from the front, his apparent love of jumping over all the things, the fact that some rails do not seem to have the ability to have bodies thrown over them, and the magic that is invisible walls that never seem to stop you except when it makes the least sense. I'm looking at you, one weird fence that I can't throw thing's over. However, these are nitpicks, and the actual game is fantastic. You constantly feel ♥♥♥♥ing awesome when you take down the target, and even when you do play the game like Ground Hog Day and abuse saves, you still feel like you've accomplished something. Every level is an intricate clockwork of amazing level design, and there is always one weakness in the security. and finding those weaknesses or seeing opportunities or even devising your own crazy plan that works in the end (With a couple hitches) is a fantastic feeling.Plus, Diana is pretty cool.

content:
Posted: August 27, 2016
												The short version: get blood money. The long version isn't so simple. Every Hitman game introduces itself with an impressive amount of class and enjoyment. Those first two levels are always so promising. As the game progresses, however, those shining promises diminish onto bitter lies. The variety of weapons and tactics you learn would lead you to believe that every level will be thick with choices as to how you'll progress. There should be a variety of ways to kill your targets. There should be thought provoking scenarios that will make you feel like you've accomplished something upon completing them. Instead you're given two, maybe three ways to get within attack range of your target. From there you can do a "silent assasssin attack" that will rarely be something you'll figure out without immersion breaking trial and error. Instead you'll end up throwing a hammer at his/her head or just shooting them and running away with a terrified Zoidberg "whoop whoop whoop whoop!". I've never seen a sandbox game that so actively discourages exploration and experimentation. Enemies pop in and out of rooms with the predictability of pokemon in tall grass, the game intentionally thows you for a loop as to what disguise you'll need CONSTANTLY, and awkward fight controls make shooting your way out of anything a joke. In the end it is fun though. After pointlessly dying a thousand times each map becomes less chaotic and more predictable. The massive levels are very fun to run around in once you know where you're going. Killing your targets is usually satisfying which does give the game some replayability. The repetitive soundtrack is at least nice to listen to as well. All in all I just barely give this game three stars. The cool concept works well and the mechanics work often enough that you usually feel somewhat in control of what's happening. This game wouldn't be so infuriating if the immersion wasn't so good before it was ripped away by a bad design choice.

content:
Posted: July 12, 2016
												Played this as a kid (probably shouldn't have considering the sexual themes and violence but ♥♥♥♥ the world) and it still holds up today. Its one of the best from the PS2/Xbox generation and looks glorious in 1080p maxed out on PC. It looks as good as  I remember, even though the PS2 version I'm sure looked worse even though it is one of the best looking PS2 games.The only issue is it can be a bit easy and sometimes all you need is the right disguise to ace a mission unlike in Silent Assasin which has diffrent mechanics in terms of AI in some ways. Sometimes you can just toss a bomb over a barracade in a crowded bar if you get in the right position and sneak, I did this in the Vegas mission on the 2nd highest difficulty but the highest difficulty this might be impossible to get away with.Regardless this was the pinnacle of the Hitman series. I havn't played the new 2016 game but it looks like they copied alot of Blood Moneys mechanics and threw away that awful Absolution idea, which is great.Everything about the setup was perfect, upgrading weapons before it was common place in games, hop in any mission you want as long as you are that far in the game at any difficulty you want on the fly aswell as the missions being relatively short depending on your play style. Free form gameplay where you can either just gun your way through every level or sneak your way through and you get a rating afterwards based on your actions. It was really one of my favorite games from one of the best devs of the era IO interactive was really on their game back then. Shame Freedom Fighters isn't on steam.

Posted: July 25, 2016
Still The BestHitman has always been about two basic things; stealth and killing. Truly the series has become iconic since its original release 16 years ago. This game is, in my opinion, the apex of the series, tying the finest of all the games in the series together brilliantly. A swan song perhaps as this was last in the series before IO had been bought, along with this franchise, by SquareEnix.In this game Agent 47 returns in a series of missions as recounted during an interview and flashbacks between a reporter and the former director for the FBI. The story is actually interesting and builds to a pretty unique conclusion. The missions and settings are well diverse if not seemingly nonsensically strung together. As agent 47 it is up to the player to decide how ton carry out these missions.If the player chooses to go in guns blazing, there will be witnesses which will more than affect the mission and the score, it will also affect future missions via 'Notoriety'. The more notorious Agent 47 becomes the harder missions may also become as guards and civilians will be more suspicious, making the stealth aspect all the more difficult.If the player chooses to be stealthy the game really shines. Watching guard patterns and memorizing hiding places is only part of the challenge. Often there are alternative ways into and out of areas, or little secrets to ferret out that might make performing the mission more interesting. Intel may be bought with cash earned on missions that will offer tips or clues as to where items may be stashed for use, or a secret about the target or people in the area that might prove handy. Ultimately these are not necessary as the player has many options to take advantage of. The truly masterful player can earn higher ratings and less notoriety if hits are performed as covertly as possible, or better yet, made to appear as 'accidents'. Disguises are also fun, and a bit silly, but then what could possibly be out of place when a six foot tall, frowning bald man with a bar-code on his head dresses like Santa and pours an aphrodisiac into another guy's drink?At the end of each mission the player's performance is evaluated in the form of a newspaper page, which is also loaded with Easter eggs regarding the story and game. Fire a lot of bullets and the story about the assassination will describe the killer as unprofessional, amateurish, even sloppy. Little touches like this really help set the experience apart from other games, lending humor and finesse to the scoring system that, even ten years after the initial release, remains very unique.There are issues, however. The game is, as mentioned, over ten years old, having been first released in spring 2006. The graphics are very dated, though this does nothing to really hurt the game itself. Other problems are bigger, but still not really too bad. The AI can behave a little oddly, at times I'd seen a civilian simply standing in place like a mannequin with their arms out, then suddenly come to life and begin freaking out. Other times the guards might inexplicably repeat a task and throw off their routine, making the mission a bit harder as the game does not play out as it was intended. It was a curve-ball, but I didn't mind the added challenge of trying to work around something totally unexpected. Some of the animations are aggravatingly overdone, making Agent 47 kind of take his time doing certain things rather needlessly. Pulling a fuse isn't just pulling a fuse; it's him opening the box, reaching into the box with a kind of unnecessary flourish, peering around, pulling out the fuses, peering around again, and closing the fuse box. This is the kind of thing that can get the player discovered and feels aggravating. Again, not a game breaking issue, but in a game where timing is important I’d like for things to move a little more simply and less like a lengthy ballet. Again, not a game breaker, but still very annoying.Overall this is a fantastic game with a lot to offer stealth fans, and everything Hitman fans love about the series. Recommended!Pros: High replay value Satisfying no matter how you choose to complete missions Excellent musical score by Jesper Kyd Controls are excellent Missions are fun Rewards practice and experience Good story Cons: Graphically dated Lengthy animations for tasks Some bugs can break missions forcing restarts Sometimes wonky AI No achievements (if you care about that) No game pad supportI have played three version of this game; first on Xbox, then Xbox 360 (with all achievements), and now finally on PC. This is the best in the series, perfectly executed...(pun intended.)

Eu gastei mais de 130 horas com esse jogo na outra conta, você pode repetir as missões e fazer de maneira completamente diferente, aumentando a dificuldade e usando estratégias única. You need to think very well in what you are going to do and act quickly when you decide what to do. its mechanics make the game complex, but it still enjoyable and fun. I've spent more than 130 hours playing the game in another account, you can repeat the same missions a thousand times and do it in a completly different way everytime you do it. Things like knock everyone out in the mission A New Life make this game much longer than it seems and much better than simplely complete missions.Knowing mechanics and understanding A.I. gives you the opportunity to do real amazing things.

												As of 2017, this game still continues to be my favorite Hitman. There is lots of replayability, and at least a dozen different ways of killing your target for each level. The story takes around 10 to 12 hours, but I have over 60 and continue to play to this day. The levels are extremely fun and designed well and all feel "alive". The weapon customization is pretty good as well, but the only real weapon you need is the fiber wire and silverballers. Also this Hitman has two playstyles. If you prefer going in with a fully modded SMG and killing everyone in the level to win, you can. Or you can play as a stealthy asassin and not kill a single person other than your targets, it is up to you.If you are considering buying this game, BUY IT. Especially for it's extremely cheap price. I fyou don't have the money, wait until it goes on sale were it sometimes goes for around 2 bucks.

Posted: March 15, 2012
												The gamer in me would never let me sleep if I didnt praise this game at least in the smallest degree. Hitman Bloodmoney puts the player in the mind of Agent 47, A Clone who works as, you guessed it, a hitman. While earlier games may or may not have been great (i've heard good things about the second hitman and Contracts was fun), this game is just shy of being my favorite PC game of all time. While there are missions rather than a completely open world game, Blood Money gives you the option of completing the mission in a slew of unique, sometimes humorous ways. Before each mission you are given a list of objectives (which may update on the go) and a chance to choose what weapons you bring and the option to upgrade them with money you earn from each mission.

Posted: April 22, 2015
												Hands-down the best Hitman game ever released and one of my favorite games. The game allows you to get very creative with how you assasinate targets - moreso than any other Hitman title, by a longshot, and has really great levels.For those unfamiliar, Hitman games are a series of sort of "sandbox" large levels in which you must kill one or more characters. You spawn on the map and it's up to you. WIll you disguise yourself as a tourist to get past the police? Will you sneak in through some strange exit? Will you use an explosion as a distraction? Will you just full rambo the whole damn place? All viable options. I recommend the game to anyone.
